123/**
124 * Class illustrating use of XQuery with Saxon as the
125 * implementation, using its native "s9api".
126 *<p>
127 * Supplies alternative, XML Query-based (as the SQL/XML standard dictates)
128 * implementation of some of SQL/XML, where the implementation in core
129 * PostgreSQL is limited to the capabilities of XPath (and XPath 1.0, at that).
130 *<p>
131 * Without the syntatic sugar built into the core PostgreSQL parser, calls to
132 * a function in this class can look a bit more verbose in SQL, but reflect a
133 * straightforward rewriting from the standard syntax. For example, suppose
134 * there is a table {@code catalog_as_xml} with a single row whose {@code x}
135 * column is a (respectably sized) XML document recording the stuff in
136 * {@code pg_catalog}. It could be created like this:
137 *<pre>
138 * CREATE TABLE catalog_as_xml(x) AS
139 *   SELECT schema_to_xml('pg_catalog', false, true, '');
140 *</pre>
141 *<h2>Functions/predicates from ISO 9075-14 SQL/XML</h2>
142 *<h3>XMLQUERY</h3>
143 *<p>
144 * In the syntax of the SQL/XML standard, here is a query that would return
145 * an XML element representing the declaration of a function with a specified
146 * name:
147 *<pre>
148 * SELECT XMLQUERY('/pg_catalog/pg_proc[proname eq $FUNCNAME]'
149 *                 PASSING BY VALUE x, 'numeric_avg' AS FUNCNAME
150 *                 RETURNING CONTENT EMPTY ON EMPTY)
151 * FROM catalog_as_xml;
152 *</pre>
153 *<p>
154 * It binds the 'context item' of the query to {@code x}, and the {@code NAME}
155 * parameter to the given value, then evaluates the query and returns XML
156 * "CONTENT" (a tree structure with a document node at the root, but not
157 * necessarily meeting all the requirements of an XML "DOCUMENT"). It can be
158 * rewritten as this call to the {@link #xq_ret_content xq_ret_content} method:
159 *<pre>
160 * SELECT javatest.xq_ret_content('/pg_catalog/pg_proc[proname eq $FUNCNAME]',
161 *                                PASSING =&gt; p, nullOnEmpty =&gt; false)
162 * FROM catalog_as_xml,
163 * LATERAL (SELECT x AS ".", 'numeric_avg' AS "FUNCNAME") AS p;
164 *</pre>
165 *<p>
166 * In the rewritten form, the form of result wanted ({@code RETURNING CONTENT})
167 * is implicit in the called function name ({@code xq_ret_content}), and the
168 * parameters to pass to the query are moved out to a separate {@code SELECT}
169 * that supplies their values, types, and names (with the context item now given
170 * the name ".") and is passed by its alias into the query function.
171 *<p>
172 * Because of an unconditional uppercasing that PL/Java's JDBC driver currently
173 * applies to column names, any parameter names, such as {@code FUNCNAME} above,
174 * must be spelled in uppercase where used in the XQuery text, or they will not
175 * be recognized. Because the unconditional uppercasing is highly likely to be
176 * dropped in a future PL/Java release, it is wisest until then to use only
177 * parameter names that really are uppercase, both in the XQuery text where they
178 * are used and in the SQL expression that supplies them. In PostgreSQL,
179 * identifiers that are not quoted are <em>lower</em>cased, so they must be both
180 * uppercase and quoted, in the SQL syntax, to be truly uppercase.
181 *<p>
182 * In the standard, parameters and results (of XML types) can be passed
183 * {@code BY VALUE} or {@code BY REF}, where the latter means that the same
184 * nodes will retain their XQuery node identities over calls (note that this is
185 * a meaning unrelated to what "by value" and "by reference" usually mean in
186 * PostgreSQL's documentation). PostgreSQL's implementation of the XML type
187 * provides no way for {@code BY REF} semantics to be implemented, so everything
188 * happening here happens {@code BY VALUE} implicitly, and does not need to be
189 * specified.
190 *<h3>XMLEXISTS</h3>
191 *<p>
192 * The function {@link #xmlexists xmlexists} here implements the
193 * standard function of the same name. Because it is the same name, it has to
194 * be either schema-qualified or double-quoted in a call to avoid confusion
195 * with the reserved word. In the syntax of the SQL/XML standard, here is a
196 * query returning a boolean value indicating whether a function with the
197 * specified name is declared:
198 *<pre>
199 * SELECT XMLEXISTS('/pg_catalog/pg_proc[proname eq $FUNCNAME]'
200 *                  PASSING BY VALUE x, 'numeric_avg' AS FUNCNAME)
201 * FROM catalog_as_xml;
202 *</pre>
203 *<p>
204 * It can be rewritten as this call to the {@link #xmlexists xmlexists} method:
205 *<pre>
206 * SELECT "xmlexists"('/pg_catalog/pg_proc[proname eq $FUNCNAME]',
207 *                    PASSING =&gt; p)
208 * FROM catalog_as_xml,
209 * LATERAL (SELECT x AS ".", 'numeric_avg' AS "FUNCNAME") AS p;
210 *</pre>
211 *<h3>XMLTABLE</h3>
212 *<p>
213 * The function {@link #xmltable xmltable} here implements (much of) the
214 * standard function of the same name. Because it is the same name, it has to
215 * be either schema-qualified or double-quoted in a call to avoid confusion
216 * with the reserved word. A rewritten form of the <a href=
217'https://www.postgresql.org/docs/10/static/functions-xml.html#FUNCTIONS-XML-PROCESSING-XMLTABLE'
218>first example in the PostgreSQL manual</a> could be:
219 *<pre>
220 * SELECT xmltable.*
221 * FROM
222 *  xmldata,
223 *
224 *  LATERAL (SELECT data AS ".", 'not specified'::text AS "DPREMIER") AS p,
225 *
226 *  "xmltable"('//ROWS/ROW', PASSING =&gt; p, COLUMNS =&gt; ARRAY[
227 *   'data(@id)', null, 'COUNTRY_NAME',
228 *   'COUNTRY_ID', 'SIZE[@unit eq "sq_km"]',
229 *   'concat(SIZE[@unit ne "sq_km"], " ", SIZE[@unit ne "sq_km"]/@unit)',
230 *   'let $e := PREMIER_NAME
231 *    return if ( empty($e) )then $DPREMIER else $e'
232 *  ]) AS (
233 *   id int, ordinality int8, "COUNTRY_NAME" text, country_id text,
234 *   size_sq_km float, size_other text, premier_name text
235 *  );
236 *</pre>
237 *<p>
238 * In the first column expression, without the {@code data()} function, the
239 * result would be a bare attribute node (one not enclosed in an XML element).
240 * Many implementations will accept a bare attribute as a column expression
241 * result, and simply assume the attribute's value is wanted, but it appears
242 * that a strict implementation of the spec must raise {@code err:XPTY0004} in
243 * such a case. This implementation is meant to be strict, so the attribute is
244 * wrapped in {@code data()} to extract and return its value. (See
245 * "About bare attribute nodes" in {@link #assignRowValues assignRowValues}
246 * for more explanation.)
247 *<p>
248 * The {@code DPREMIER} parameter passed from SQL to the XQuery expression is
249 * spelled in uppercase (and also, in the SQL expression supplying it, quoted),
250 * for the reasons explained above for the {@code xq_ret_content} function.
251 *<h3>XMLCAST</h3>
252 *<p>
253 * An ISO standard cast expression like
254 *<pre>
255 * XMLCAST(v AS wantedtype)
256 *</pre>
257 * can be rewritten with this idiom and the {@link #xmlcast xmlcast} function
258 * provided here:
259 *<pre>
260 * (SELECT r FROM (SELECT v) AS o, xmlcast(o) AS (r wantedtype))
261 *</pre>
262 *<h2>XQuery regular-expression functions in ISO 9075-2 Foundations</h2>
263 * The methods {@link #like_regex like_regex},
264 * {@link #occurrences_regex occurrences_regex},
265 * {@link #position_regex position_regex},
266 * {@link #substring_regex substring_regex}, and
267 * {@link #translate_regex translate_regex} provide, with slightly altered
268 * syntax, the ISO SQL predicate and functions of the same names.
269 *<p>
270 * For the moment, they will only match newlines in the way W3C XQuery
271 * specifies, not in the more-flexible Unicode-compatible way ISO SQL specifies,
272 * and for the ones where ISO SQL allows {@code USING CHARACTERS} or
273 * {@code USING OCTETS}, only {@code USING CHARACTERS} will work.
274 *<h2>Extensions</h2>
275 *<h3>XQuery module prolog allowed</h3>
276 *<p>
277 * Where any function here accepts an XQuery
278 *<a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xquery-31/#id-expressions'
279 *>"expression"</a> according to the SQL specification, in fact an XQuery
280 *<a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xquery-31/#dt-main-module'
281 *>"main module"</a> will be accepted. Therefore, the query can be preceded by
282 * a prolog declaring namespaces, options, local variables and functions, etc.
283 *<h3>Saxon extension to XQuery regular expressions</h3>
284 *<p>
285 * Saxon's implementation of XQuery regular expressions will accept a
286 * nonstandard <em>flag</em> string ending with {@code ;j} to use Java regular
287 * expressions rather than XQuery ones. That extension is available in the
288 * XQuery regular-expression methods provided here.
289 * @author Chapman Flack
290 */
291public class S9 implements ResultSetProvider.Large
292{
293    private S9(
294        XdmSequenceIterator<XdmItem> xsi,
295        XQueryEvaluator[] columnXQEs,
296        SequenceType[] columnStaticTypes,
297        XMLBinary enc)
298    {
299        m_sequenceIterator = xsi;
300        m_columnXQEs = columnXQEs;
301        m_columnStaticTypes = columnStaticTypes;
302        m_atomize = new AtomizingFunction [ columnStaticTypes.length ];
303        m_xmlbinary = enc;
304    }
305
306    final XdmSequenceIterator<XdmItem> m_sequenceIterator;
307    final XQueryEvaluator[] m_columnXQEs;
308    final SequenceType[] m_columnStaticTypes;
309    final SequenceType s_01untypedAtomic = makeSequenceType(
310        ItemType.UNTYPED_ATOMIC, OccurrenceIndicator.ZERO_OR_ONE);
311    final AtomizingFunction[] m_atomize;
312    final XMLBinary m_xmlbinary;
313    Binding.Assemblage m_outBindings;
314
315    static final Connection s_dbc;
316    static final Processor s_s9p = new Processor(false);
317    static final ItemTypeFactory s_itf = new ItemTypeFactory(s_s9p);
318
319    static final Pattern s_intervalSigns;
320    static final Pattern s_intervalSignSite;
321
322    enum XMLBinary { HEX, BASE64 };
323    enum Nulls { ABSENT, NIL };
324
325    static
326    {
327        try
328        {
329            s_dbc = DriverManager.getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
330
331            /*
332             * XML Schema thinks an ISO 8601 duration must have no sign
333             * anywhere but at the very beginning before the P. PostgreSQL
334             * thinks that's the one place a sign must never be, and instead
335             * it should appear in front of every numeric field. (PostgreSQL
336             * accepts input where the signs vary, and there are cases where it
337             * cannot be normalized away: P1M-1D is a thing, and can't be
338             * simplified until anchored at a date to know how long the month
339             * is! The XML Schema type simply can't represent that, so mapping
340             * of such a value must simply fail, as we'll ensure below.)
341             * So, here's a regex with a capturing group for a leading -, and
342             * one for any field-leading -, and one for the absence of a field-
343             * leading -. Any PostgreSQL or XS duration ought to match overall,
344             * but the capturing group matches should be either (f,f,t) or
345             * (f,t,f) for a PostgreSQL duration, or either (f,f,t) or (t,f,t)
346             * for an XS duration. (f,t,t) would be a PostgreSQL interval with
347             * mixed signs, and inconvertible.
348             */
349            s_intervalSigns = Pattern.compile(
350            "(-)?+(?:[PYMWDTH](?:(?:(-)|())\\d++)?+)++(?:(?:[.,]\\d*+)?+S)?+");
351            /*
352             * To convert from the leading-sign form, need to find every spot
353             * where a digit follows a [PYMWDTH] to insert a - there.
354             */
355            s_intervalSignSite = Pattern.compile("(?<=[PYMWDTH])(?=\\d)");
356        }
357        catch ( SQLException e )
358        {
359            throw new ExceptionInInitializerError(e);
360        }
361    }
362
363    static class PredefinedQueryHolders
364    {
365        static final XQueryCompiler s_xqc = s_s9p.newXQueryCompiler();
366        static final QName s_qEXPR = new QName("EXPR");
367
368        static class DocumentWrapUnwrap
369        {
370            static final XQueryExecutable INSTANCE;
371
372            static
373            {
374                try
375                {
376                    INSTANCE = s_xqc.compile(
377                        "declare construction preserve;" +
378                        "declare variable $EXPR as item()* external;" +
379                        "data(document{$EXPR}/child::node())");
380                }
381                catch ( SaxonApiException e )
382                {
383                    throw new ExceptionInInitializerError(e);
384                }
385            }
386        }
387    }
388
389    /**
390     * PostgreSQL (as of 12) lacks the XMLTEXT function, so here it is.
391     *<p>
392     * As long as PostgreSQL does not have the {@code XML(SEQUENCE)} type,
393     * this can only be the {@code XMLTEXT(sve RETURNING CONTENT)} flavor, which
394     * does create a text node with {@code sve} as its value, but returns the
395     * text node wrapped in a document node.
396     *<p>
397     * This function doesn't actually require Saxon, but otherwise fits in with
398     * the theme here, implementing missing parts of SQL/XML for PostgreSQL.
399     * @param sve SQL string value to use in a text node
400     * @return XML content, the text node wrapped in a document node
401     */
402    @Function(schema="javatest")
403    public static SQLXML xmltext(String sve) throws SQLException
404    {
405        SQLXML rx = s_dbc.createSQLXML();
406        ContentHandler ch = rx.setResult(SAXResult.class).getHandler();
407
408        try
409        {
410            ch.startDocument();
411            /*
412             * It seems XMLTEXT() should be such a trivial function to write,
413             * but already it reveals a subtlety in the SAX API docs. They say
414             * the third argument to characters() is "the number of characters
415             * to read from the array" and that follows a long discussion of how
416             * individual characters can (with code points above U+FFFF) consist
417             * of more than one Java char value.
418             *
419             * And yet, when you try it out (and include some characters above
420             * U+FFFF in the input), you discover the third argument isn't the
421             * number of characters, has to be the number of Java char values.
422             */
423            ch.characters(sve.toCharArray(), 0, sve.length());
424            ch.endDocument();
425        }
426        catch ( SAXException e )
427        {
428            rx.free();
429            throw new SQLException(e.getMessage(), e);
430        }
431
432        return rx;
433    }
434
435    /**
436     * An implementation of XMLCAST.
437     *<p>
438     * Will be declared to take and return type {@code RECORD}, where each must
439     * have exactly one component, just because that makes it easy to use
440     * existing JDBC metadata queries to find out the operand and target SQL
441     * data types.
442     *<p>
443     * Serving suggestion: rewrite this ISO standard expression
444     *<pre>
445     * XMLCAST(v AS wantedtype)
446     *</pre>
447     * to this idiomatic one:
448     *<pre>
449     * (SELECT r FROM (SELECT v) AS o, xmlcast(o) AS (r wantedtype))
450     *</pre>
451     * @param operand a one-row, one-column record supplied by the caller, whose
452     * one typed value is the operand to be cast.
453     * @param base64 true if binary SQL values should be base64-encoded in XML;
454     * if false (the default), values will be encoded in hex.
455     * @param target a one-row, one-column record supplied by PL/Java from the
456     * {@code AS} clause after the function call, whose one column's type is the
457     * type to be cast to.
458     */
459    @Function(
460        schema="javatest",
461        type="pg_catalog.record",
462        onNullInput=CALLED,
463        settings="IntervalStyle TO iso_8601"
464    )
465    public static boolean xmlcast(
466        ResultSet operand, @SQLType(defaultValue="false") Boolean base64,
467        ResultSet target)
468        throws SQLException
469    {
470        if ( null == operand )
471            throw new SQLDataException(
472                "xmlcast \"operand\" must be (in this implementation) " +
473                "a non-null row type", "22004");
474
475        if ( null == base64 )
476            throw new SQLDataException(
477                "xmlcast \"base64\" must be true or false, not null", "22004");
478        XMLBinary enc = base64 ? XMLBinary.BASE64 : XMLBinary.HEX;
479
480        assert null != target : "PL/Java supplied a null output record???";
481
482        if ( 1 != operand.getMetaData().getColumnCount() )
483            throw new SQLDataException(
484                "xmlcast \"operand\" must be a row type with exactly " +
485                "one component", "22000");
486
487        if ( 1 != target.getMetaData().getColumnCount() )
488            throw new SQLDataException(
489                "xmlcast \"target\" must be a row type with exactly " +
490                "one component", "22000");
491
492        Binding.Parameter op =
493            new BindingsFromResultSet(operand, false).iterator().next();
494
495        Binding.Parameter tg =
496            new BindingsFromResultSet(target, null).iterator().next();
497
498        int sd = op.typeJDBC();
499        int td = tg.typeJDBC();
500
501        int castcase =
502            (Types.SQLXML == sd ? 2 : 0) | (Types.SQLXML == td ? 1 : 0);
503
504        switch ( castcase )
505        {
506        case 0: // neither sd nor td is an XML type
507            throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
508                "at least one of xmlcast \"operand\" or \"target\" must " +
509                "be of XML type", "42804");
510        case 3: // both XML
511            /*
512             * In an implementation closely following the spec, this case would
513             * be handled in parse analysis and rewritten from an XMLCAST to a
514             * plain CAST, and this code would never see it. This is a plain
515             * example function without benefit of a parser that can do that.
516             * In a DBMS with all the various SQL:2006 XML subtypes, there would
517             * be nontrivial work to do here, but casting from PostgreSQL's one
518             * XML type to itself is more of a warm-up exercise.
519             */
520            target.updateSQLXML(1, operand.getSQLXML(1));
521            return true;
522        case 1: // something non-XML being cast to XML
523            assertCanCastAsXmlSequence(sd, "operand");
524            Object v = op.valueJDBC();
525            if ( null == v )
526            {
527                target.updateNull(1);
528                return true;
529            }
530            ItemType xsbt =
531                mapSQLDataTypeToXMLSchemaDataType(op, enc, Nulls.ABSENT);
532            Iterator<XdmItem> tv =
533                xmlCastAsSequence(v, enc, xsbt).iterator();
534            try
535            {
536                target.updateSQLXML(1,
537                    returnContent(tv, /*nullOnEmpty*/ false));
538            }
539            catch ( SaxonApiException | XPathException e )
540            {
541                throw new SQLException(e.getMessage(), "10000", e);
542            }
543            return true;
544        case 2: // XML being cast to something non-XML
545            assertCanCastAsXmlSequence(td, "target");
546            SQLXML sx = operand.getSQLXML(1);
547            if ( null == sx )
548            {
549                target.updateNull(1);
550                return true;
551            }
552            DocumentBuilder dBuilder = s_s9p.newDocumentBuilder();
553            Source source = sx.getSource(null);
554            try
555            {
556                XdmValue xv = dBuilder.build(source);
557                XQueryEvaluator xqe =
558                    PredefinedQueryHolders.DocumentWrapUnwrap.INSTANCE.load();
559                xqe.setExternalVariable(PredefinedQueryHolders.s_qEXPR, xv);
560                xv = xqe.evaluate();
561                /*
562                 * It's zero-or-one, or XPTY0004 was thrown here.
563                 */
564                if ( 0 == xv.size() )
565                {
566                    target.updateNull(1);
567                    return true;
568                }
569                XdmAtomicValue av = (XdmAtomicValue)xv;
570                xmlCastAsNonXML(
571                    av, ItemType.UNTYPED_ATOMIC, tg, target, 1, enc);
572            }
573            catch ( SaxonApiException | XPathException e )
574            {
575                throw new SQLException(e.getMessage(), "10000", e);
576            }
577            return true;
578        }
579
580        throw new SQLFeatureNotSupportedException(
581            "cannot yet xmlcast from " + op.typePG() +
582            " to " + tg.typePG(), "0A000");
583    }
584
585    /**
586     * A simple example corresponding to {@code XMLQUERY(expression
587     * PASSING BY VALUE passing RETURNING CONTENT {NULL|EMPTY} ON EMPTY)}.
588     * @param expression An XQuery expression. Must not be {@code null} (in the
589     * SQL standard {@code XMLQUERY} syntax, it is not even allowed to be an
590     * SQL expression at all, only a string literal).
591     * @param nullOnEmpty pass {@code true} to get a null return in place of
592     * an empty sequence, or {@code false} to just get the empty sequence.
593     * @param passing A row value whose columns will be supplied to the query
594     * as parameters. Columns with names (typically supplied with {@code AS})
595     * appear as predeclared external variables with matching names (in no
596     * namespace) in the query, with types derived from the SQL types of the
597     * row value's columns. There may be one (and no more than one)
598     * column with {@code AS "."} which, if present, will be bound as the
599     * context item. (The name {@code ?column?}, which PostgreSQL uses for an
600     * otherwise-unnamed column, is also accepted, which will often allow the
601     * context item to be specified with no {@code AS} at all. Beware, though,
602     * that PostgreSQL likes to invent column names from any function or type
603     * name that may appear in the value expression, so this shorthand will not
604     * always work, while {@code AS "."} will.) PL/Java's internal JDBC uppercases all column
605     * names, so any uses of the corresponding variables in the query must have
606     * the names in upper case. It is safest to also uppercase their appearances
607     * in the SQL (for which, in PostgreSQL, they must be quoted), so that the
608     * JDBC uppercasing is not being relied on. It is likely to be dropped in a
609     * future PL/Java release.
610     * @param namespaces An even-length String array where, of each pair of
611     * consecutive entries, the first is a namespace prefix and the second is
612     * the URI to which to bind it. The zero-length prefix sets the default
613     * element and type namespace; if the prefix has zero length, the URI may
614     * also have zero length, to declare that unprefixed elements are in no
615     * namespace.
616     */
617    @Function(
618        schema="javatest",
619        onNullInput=CALLED,
620        settings="IntervalStyle TO iso_8601"
621    )
622    public static SQLXML xq_ret_content(
623        String expression, Boolean nullOnEmpty,
624        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet passing,
625        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) String[] namespaces)
626        throws SQLException
627    {
628        /*
629         * The expression itself may not be null (in the standard, it isn't
630         * even allowed to be dynamic, and can only be a string literal!).
631         */
632        if ( null == expression )
633            throw new SQLDataException(
634                "XMLQUERY expression may not be null", "22004");
635
636        if ( null == nullOnEmpty )
637            throw new SQLDataException(
638                "XMLQUERY nullOnEmpty may not be null", "22004");
639
640        try
641        {
642            XdmSequenceIterator<XdmItem> x1 =
643                evalXQuery(expression, passing, namespaces);
644            return null == x1 ? null : returnContent(x1, nullOnEmpty);
645        }
646        catch ( SaxonApiException | XPathException e )
647        {
648            throw new SQLException(e.getMessage(), "10000", e);
649        }
650    }
651
652    /**
653     * An implementation of {@code XMLEXISTS(expression
654     * PASSING BY VALUE passing)}, using genuine XQuery.
655     * @param expression An XQuery expression. Must not be {@code null} (in the
656     * SQL standard {@code XMLQUERY} syntax, it is not even allowed to be an
657     * SQL expression at all, only a string literal).
658     * @param passing A row value whose columns will be supplied to the query
659     * as parameters. Columns with names (typically supplied with {@code AS})
660     * appear as predeclared external variables with matching names (in no
661     * namespace) in the query, with types derived from the SQL types of the
662     * row value's columns. There may be one (and no more than one)
663     * column with {@code AS "."} which, if present, will be bound as the
664     * context item. (The name {@code ?column?}, which PostgreSQL uses for an
665     * otherwise-unnamed column, is also accepted, which will often allow the
666     * context item to be specified with no {@code AS} at all. Beware, though,
667     * that PostgreSQL likes to invent column names from any function or type
668     * name that may appear in the value expression, so this shorthand will not
669     * always work, while {@code AS "."} will.) PL/Java's internal JDBC uppercases all column
670     * names, so any uses of the corresponding variables in the query must have
671     * the names in upper case. It is safest to also uppercase their appearances
672     * in the SQL (for which, in PostgreSQL, they must be quoted), so that the
673     * JDBC uppercasing is not being relied on. It is likely to be dropped in a
674     * future PL/Java release.
675     * @param namespaces An even-length String array where, of each pair of
676     * consecutive entries, the first is a namespace prefix and the second is
677     * the URI to which to bind it. The zero-length prefix sets the default
678     * element and type namespace; if the prefix has zero length, the URI may
679     * also have zero length, to declare that unprefixed elements are in no
680     * namespace.
681     * @return True if the expression evaluates to a nonempty sequence, false if
682     * it evaluates to an empty one. Null if a context item is passed and its
683     * SQL value is null.
684     */
685    @Function(
686        schema="javatest",
687        onNullInput=CALLED,
688        settings="IntervalStyle TO iso_8601"
689    )
690    public static Boolean xmlexists(
691        String expression,
692        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet passing,
693        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) String[] namespaces)
694        throws SQLException
695    {
696        /*
697         * The expression itself may not be null (in the standard, it isn't
698         * even allowed to be dynamic, and can only be a string literal!).
699         */
700        if ( null == expression )
701            throw new SQLDataException(
702                "XMLEXISTS expression may not be null", "22004");
703
704        XdmSequenceIterator<XdmItem> x1 =
705            evalXQuery(expression, passing, namespaces);
706        if ( null == x1 )
707            return null;
708        if ( ! x1.hasNext() )
709            return false;
710        x1.close();
711        return true;
712    }
713
714    /**
715     * Implementation factor of XMLEXISTS and XMLQUERY.
716     * @return null if a context item is passed and its SQL value is null
717     */
718    private static XdmSequenceIterator<XdmItem> evalXQuery(
719        String expression, ResultSet passing, String[] namespaces)
720        throws SQLException
721    {
722        Binding.Assemblage bindings = new BindingsFromResultSet(passing, true);
723
724        try
725        {
726            XQueryCompiler xqc = createStaticContextWithPassedTypes(
727                bindings, namespaceBindings(namespaces));
728
729            XQueryEvaluator xqe = xqc.compile(expression).load();
730
731            if ( storePassedValuesInDynamicContext(xqe, bindings, true) )
732                return null;
733
734            /*
735             * For now, punt on whether the <XQuery expression> is evaluated
736             * with XML 1.1 or 1.0 lexical rules....  XXX
737             */
738            return xqe.iterator();
739        }
740        catch ( SaxonApiException | XPathException e )
741        {
742            throw new SQLException(e.getMessage(), "10000", e);
743        }
744    }
745
746    /**
747     * Perform the final steps of <em>something</em> {@code RETURNING CONTENT},
748     * with or without {@code nullOnEmpty}.
749     *<p>
750     * The effects are to be the same as if the supplied sequence were passed
751     * as {@code $EXPR} to {@code document{$EXPR}}.
752     */
753    private static SQLXML returnContent(
754        Iterator<XdmItem> x, boolean nullOnEmpty)
755    throws SQLException, SaxonApiException, XPathException
756    {
757        if ( nullOnEmpty  &&  ! x.hasNext() )
758            return null;
759
760        SQLXML rsx = s_dbc.createSQLXML();
761        /*
762         * Keep this simple by requesting a specific type of Result rather
763         * than letting PL/Java choose. It happens (though this is a detail of
764         * the implementation) that SAXResult won't be a bad choice.
765         */
766        SAXResult sr = rsx.setResult(SAXResult.class);
767        /*
768         * Michael Kay recommends the following as equivalent to the SQL/XML-
769         * mandated behavior of evaluating document{$x}.
770         * https://sourceforge.net/p/saxon/mailman/message/36969060/
771         */
772        SAXDestination d = new SAXDestination(sr.getHandler());
773        Receiver r = d.getReceiver(
774            s_s9p.getUnderlyingConfiguration().makePipelineConfiguration(),
775            new SerializationProperties());
776        r.open();
777        while ( x.hasNext() )
778            r.append(x.next().getUnderlyingValue());
779        r.close();
780        return rsx;
781    }
782
783    /**
784     * An implementation of (much of) XMLTABLE, using genuine XML Query.
785     *<p>
786     * The {@code columns} array must supply a valid XML Query expression for
787     * every column in the column definition list that follows the call of this
788     * function in SQL, except that the column for ordinality, if wanted, is
789     * identified by a {@code null} entry in {@code columns}. Syntax sugar in
790     * the standard allows an omitted column expression to imply an element test
791     * for an element with the same name as the column; that doesn't work here.
792     *<p>
793     * For now, this implementation lacks the ability to specify defaults for
794     * when a column expression produces an empty sequence. It is possible to
795     * do defaults explicitly by rewriting a query expression <em>expr</em> as
796     * {@code let $e := }<em>expr</em>{@code return if(empty($e))then $D else $e}
797     * and supplying the default <em>D</em> as another query parameter, though
798     * such defaults will be evaluated only once when {@code xmltable} is called
799     * and will not be able to refer to other values in an output row.
800     * @param rows The single XQuery expression whose result sequence generates
801     * the rows of the resulting table. Must not be null.
802     * @param columns Array of XQuery expressions, exactly as many as result
803     * columns in the column definition list that follows the SQL call to this
804     * function. This array must not be null. It is allowed for one element (and
805     * no more than one) to be null, marking the corresponding column to be
806     * "FOR ORDINALITY" (the column must be of "exact numeric with scale zero"
807     * type; PostgreSQL supports 64-bit row counters, so {@code int8} is
808     * recommended).
809     * @param passing A row value whose columns will be supplied to the query
810     * as parameters, just as described for
811     * {@link #xq_ret_content xq_ret_content()}. If a context item is supplied,
812     * it is the context item for the {@code rows} query (the {@code columns}
813     * queries get their context item from the {@code rows} query's result). Any
814     * named parameters supplied here are available both in the {@code rows}
815     * expression and (though this goes beyond the standard) in every expression
816     * of {@code columns}, with their values unchanging from row to row.
817     * @param namespaces An even-length String array where, of each pair of
818     * consecutive entries, the first is a namespace prefix and the second is
819     * to URI to which to bind it, just as described for
820     * {@link #xq_ret_content xq_ret_content()}.
821     * @param base64 whether the effective, in-scope 'xmlbinary' setting calls
822     * for base64 or (the default, false) hexadecimal.
823     */
824    @Function(
825        schema="javatest",
826        onNullInput=CALLED,
827        settings="IntervalStyle TO iso_8601"
828    )
829    public static ResultSetProvider xmltable(
830        String rows, String[] columns,
831        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) ResultSet passing,
832        @SQLType(defaultValue={}) String[] namespaces,
833        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") Boolean base64)
834        throws SQLException
835    {
836        if ( null == rows )
837            throw new SQLDataException(
838                "XMLTABLE row expression may not be null", "22004");
839
840        if ( null == columns )
841            throw new SQLDataException(
842                "XMLTABLE columns expression array may not be null", "22004");
843
844        if ( null == base64 )
845            throw new SQLDataException(
846                "XMLTABLE base64 parameter may not be null", "22004");
847        XMLBinary enc = base64 ? XMLBinary.BASE64 : XMLBinary.HEX;
848
849        Binding.Assemblage rowBindings =
850            new BindingsFromResultSet(passing, true);
851
852        Iterable<Map.Entry<String,String>> namespacepairs =
853            namespaceBindings(namespaces);
854
855        XQueryEvaluator[] columnXQEs = new XQueryEvaluator[ columns.length ];
856        SequenceType[] columnStaticTypes = new SequenceType[ columns.length ];
857
858        try
859        {
860            XQueryCompiler rowXQC = createStaticContextWithPassedTypes(
861                rowBindings, namespacepairs);
862
863            XQueryExecutable rowXQX = rowXQC.compile(rows);
864
865            Binding.Assemblage columnBindings =
866                new BindingsFromXQX(rowXQX, rowBindings);
867
868            XQueryCompiler columnXQC = createStaticContextWithPassedTypes(
869                columnBindings, namespacepairs);
870
871            boolean ordinalitySeen = false;
872            for ( int i = 0; i < columns.length; ++ i )
873            {
874                String expr = columns[i];
875                if ( null == expr )
876                {
877                    if ( ordinalitySeen )
878                        throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
879                            "No more than one column expression may be null " +
880                            "(=> \"for ordinality\")", "42611");
881                    ordinalitySeen = true;
882                    continue;
883                }
884                XQueryExecutable columnXQX = columnXQC.compile(expr);
885                columnStaticTypes[i] = makeSequenceType(
886                    columnXQX.getResultItemType(),
887                    columnXQX.getResultCardinality());
888                columnXQEs[i] = columnXQX.load();
889                storePassedValuesInDynamicContext(
890                    columnXQEs[i], columnBindings, false);
891            }
892
893            XQueryEvaluator rowXQE = rowXQX.load();
894            XdmSequenceIterator<XdmItem> rowIterator;
895            if ( storePassedValuesInDynamicContext(rowXQE, rowBindings, true) )
896                rowIterator = (XdmSequenceIterator<XdmItem>)
897                    XdmEmptySequence.getInstance().iterator();
898            else
899                rowIterator = rowXQE.iterator();
900            return new S9(rowIterator, columnXQEs, columnStaticTypes, enc);
901        }
902        catch ( SaxonApiException | XPathException e )
903        {
904            throw new SQLException(e.getMessage(), "10000", e);
905        }
906    }
907
908    /**
909     * Called when PostgreSQL has no need for more rows of the tabular result.
910     */
911    @Override
912    public void close()
913    {
914        m_sequenceIterator.close();
915    }
916
917    /**
918     * Produce and return one row of the {@code XMLTABLE} result table per call.
919     *<p>
920     * The row expression has already been compiled and its evaluation begun,
921     * producing a sequence iterator. The column XQuery expressions have all
922     * been compiled and are ready to evaluate, and the compiler's static
923     * analysis has bounded the data types they will produce. Because of the
924     * way the set-returning function protocol works, we don't know the types
925     * of the SQL output columns yet, until the first call of this function,
926     * when the {@code receive} parameter's {@code ResultSetMetaData} can be
927     * inspected to find out. So that will be the first thing done when called
928     * with {@code currentRow} of zero.
929     *<p>
930     * Each call will then: (a) get the next value from the row expression's
931     * sequence iterator, then for each column, (b) evaluate that column's
932     * XQuery expression on the row value, and (c) assign that column's result
933     * to the SQL output column, casting to the proper type (which the SQL/XML
934     * spec has very exacting rules on how to do).
935     *<p>
936     * A note before going any further: this implementation, while fairly
937     * typical of a PostgreSQL set-returning user function, is <em>not</em> the
938     * way the SQL/XML spec defines {@code XMLTABLE}. The official behavior of
939     * {@code XMLTABLE} is defined in terms of a rewriting, at the SQL level,
940     * into a much-expanded SQL query where each result column appears as an
941     * {@code XMLQUERY} call applying the column expression, wrapped in an
942     * {@code XMLCAST} to the result column type (with a
943     * {@code CASE WHEN XMLEXISTS} thrown in to support column defaults).
944     *<p>
945     * As an ordinary user function, this example cannot rely on any fancy
946     * query rewriting during PostgreSQL's parse analysis. The slight syntax
947     * desugaring needed to transform a standard {@code XMLTABLE} call into a
948     * call of this "xmltable" is not too hard to learn and do by hand, but no
949     * one would ever want to write out by hand the whole longwinded "official"
950     * expansion prescribed in the spec. So this example is a compromise.
951     *<p>
952     * The main thing lost in the compromise is the handling of column defaults.
953     * The full rewriting with per-column SQL expressions means that each
954     * column default expression can be evaluated exactly when/if needed, which
955     * is often the desired behavior. This implementation as an ordinary
956     * function, whose arguments all get evaluated ahead of the call, can't
957     * really do that. Otherwise, there's nothing in the spec that's inherently
958     * unachievable in this implementation.
959     *<p>
960     * Which brings us to the matter of casting each column expression result
961     * to the proper type for its SQL result column.
962     *<p>
963     * Like any spec, {@code SQL/XML} does not mandate that an implementation
964     * must be done in exactly the way presented in the spec (rewritten so each
965     * column value is produced by an {@code XMLQUERY} wrapped in an
966     * {@code XMLCAST}). The requirement is to produce the equivalent result.
967     *<p>
968     * A look at the rewritten query shows that each column XQuery result value
969     * must be representable as some value in SQL's type system, not once, but
970     * twice: first as the result returned by {@code XMLQUERY} and passed along
971     * to {@code XMLCAST}, and finally with the output column's type as the
972     * result of the {@code XMLCAST}.
973     *<p>
974     * Now, the output column type can be whatever is wanted. Importantly, it
975     * can be either an XML type, or any ordinary SQL scalar type, like a
976     * {@code float} or a {@code date}. Likewise, the XQuery column expression
977     * may have produced some atomic value (like an {@code xs:double} or
978     * {@code xs:date}), or some XML node, or any sequence of any of those.
979     *<p>
980     * What are the choices for the type in the middle: the SQL value returned
981     * by {@code XMLQUERY} and passed on to {@code XMLCAST}?
982     *<p>
983     * There are two. An ISO-standard SQL {@code XMLQUERY} can specify
984     * {@code RETURNING SEQUENCE} or {@code RETURNING CONTENT}. The first option
985     * produces the type {@code XML(SEQUENCE)}, a useful type that PostgreSQL
986     * does not currently have. {@code XML(SEQUENCE)} can hold exactly whatever
987     * an XQuery expression can produce: a sequence of any length, of any
988     * mixture of atomic values and XML nodes (even such oddities as attribute
989     * nodes outside of any element), in any order. An {@code XML(SEQUENCE)}
990     * value need not look anything like what "XML" normally brings to mind.
991     *<p>
992     * With the other option, {@code RETURNING CONTENT}, the result of
993     * {@code XMLQUERY} has to be something that PostgreSQL's {@code xml} type
994     * could store: a serialized document with XML structure, but without the
995     * strict requirements of exactly one root element with no text outside it.
996     * At the limit, a completely non-XMLish string of ordinary text is
997     * perfectly acceptable XML {@code CONTENT}, as long as it uses the right
998     * {@code &...;} escapes for any characters that could look like XML markup.
999     *<p>
1000     * {@code XMLCAST} is able to accept either form as input, and deliver it
1001     * to the output column as whatever type is needed. But the spec leaves no
1002     * wiggle room as to which form to use:
1003     *<ul>
1004     *<li>If the result column type is {@code XML(SEQUENCE)}, then the
1005     * {@code XMLQUERY} is to specify {@code RETURNING SEQUENCE}. It produces
1006     * the column's result type directly, so the {@code XMLCAST} has nothing
1007     * to do.
1008     *<li>In every other case (<em>every</em> other case), the {@code XMLQUERY}
1009     * is to specify {@code RETURNING CONTENT}.
1010     *</ul>
1011     *<p>
1012     * At first blush, that second rule should sound crazy. Imagine a column
1013     * definition like
1014     *<pre>
1015     * growth float8 PATH 'math:pow(1.0 + $RATE, count(year))'
1016     *</pre>
1017     * The expression produces an {@code xs:double}, which can be assigned
1018     * directly to a PostgreSQL {@code float8}, but the rule in the spec will
1019     * have it first converted to a decimal string representation, made into
1020     * a text node, wrapped in a document node, and returned as XML, to be
1021     * passed along to {@code XMLCAST}, which parses it, discards the wrapping
1022     * document node, parses the text content as a double, and returns that as
1023     * a proper value of the result column type (which, in this example, it
1024     * already is).
1025     *<p>
1026     * The spec does not go into why this rule was chosen. The only rationale
1027     * that makes sense to me is that the {@code XML(SEQUENCE)} data type
1028     * is an SQL feature (X190) that not every implementation will support,
1029     * so the spec has to define {@code XMLTABLE} using a rewritten query that
1030     * can work on systems that do not have that type. (PostgreSQL itself, at
1031     * present, does not have it.)
1032     *<p>
1033     * The first rule, when {@code XML(SEQUENCE)} is the result column type,
1034     * will naturally never be in play except on a system that has that type, in
1035     * which case it can be used directly. But even such a system must still
1036     * produce, in all other cases, results that match what a system without
1037     * that type would produce. All those cases are therefore defined as if
1038     * going the long way through {@code XML(CONTENT)}.
1039     *<p>
1040     * Whenever the XQuery expression can be known to produce a (possibly empty
1041     * or) singleton sequence of an atomic type, the long round trip can be
1042     * shown to be idempotent, and we can skip right to casting the atomic type
1043     * to the SQL result column type. A few other cases could be short-circuited
1044     * the same way. But in general, for cases involving nodes or non-singleton
1045     * sequences, it is safest to follow the spec punctiliously; the steps are
1046     * defined in terms of XQuery constructs like {@code document {...}} and
1047     * {@code data()}, which have specs of their own with many traps for the
1048     * unwary, and the XQuery library provides implementations of them that are
1049     * already tested and correct.
1050     *<p>
1051     * Though most of the work can be done by the XQuery library, it may be
1052     * helpful to look closely at just what the specification entails.
1053     *<p>
1054     * Again, but for the case of an {@code XML(SEQUENCE)} result column, in all
1055     * other cases the result must pass through
1056     * {@code XMLQUERY(... RETURNING CONTENT EMPTY ON EMPTY)}. That, in turn, is
1057     * defined as equivalent to {@code XMLQUERY(... RETURNING SEQUENCE)} with
1058     * the result then passed to {@code XMLDOCUMENT(... RETURNING CONTENT)},
1059     * whose behavior is that of a
1060     * <a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xquery-31/#id-documentConstructors'>
1061     * document node constructor</a> in XQuery, with
1062     * <a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xquery-31/#dt-construction-mode'>
1063     * construction mode</a> {@code preserve}. The first step of that behavior
1064     * is the same as Step 1e in the processing of
1065     * <a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xquery-31/#id-content'>direct element
1066     * constructor content</a>. The remaining steps are those laid out for the
1067     * document node constructor.
1068     *<p>
1069     * Clarity demands flattening this nest of specifications into a single
1070     * ordered list of the steps to apply:
1071     *<ul>
1072     *<li>Any item in the sequence that is an array is flattened (its elements
1073     * become items in the sequence).
1074     *<li>If any item is a function, {@code err:XQTY0105} is raised.
1075     *<li>Any sequence {@code $s} of adjacent atomic values is replaced by
1076     * {@code string-join($s, ' ')}.
1077     *<li>Any XML node in the sequence is copied (as detailed in the spec).
1078     *<li>After all the above, any document node that may exist in the resulting
1079     * sequence is flattened (replaced by its children).
1080     *<li>A single text node is produced for any run of adjacent text nodes in
1081     * the sequence (including any that have newly become adjacent by the
1082     * flattening of document nodes), by concatenation with no separator (unlike
1083     * the earlier step where atomic values were concatenated with a space as
1084     * the separator).
1085     *<li>If the sequence directly contains any attribute or namespace node,
1086     * {@code err:XPTY0004} is raised. <b>More on this below.</b>
1087     *<li>The sequence resulting from the preceding steps is wrapped in one
1088     * new document node (as detailed in the spec).
1089     *</ul>
1090     *<p>
1091     * At this point, the result could be returned to SQL as a value of
1092     * {@code XML(CONTENT(ANY))} type, to be passed to an {@code XMLCAST}
1093     * invocation. This implementation avoids that, and simply proceeds with the
1094     * existing Java in-memory representation of the document tree, to the
1095     * remaining steps entailed in an {@code XMLCAST} to the output column type:
1096     *<ul>
1097     *<li>If the result column type is an XML type, rewriting would turn the
1098     * {@code XMLCAST} into a simple {@code CAST} and that's that. Otherwise,
1099     * the result column has some non-XML, SQL type, and:
1100     *<li>The algorithm "Removing XQuery document nodes from an XQuery sequence"
1101     * is applied. By construction, we know the only such node is the one the
1102     * whole sequence was recently wrapped in, two steps ago (you get your
1103     * house back, you get your dog back, you get your truck back...).
1104     *<li>That sequence of zero or more XML nodes is passed to the
1105     *<a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions-31/#func-data'>fn:data</a>
1106     * function, producing a sequence of zero or more atomic values, which will
1107     * all have type {@code xs:untypedAtomic} (because the document-wrapping
1108     * stringified any original atomic values and wrapped them in text nodes,
1109     * for which the
1110     * <a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-datamodel-31/#acc-summ-typed-value'>
1111     * typed-value</a> is {@code xs:untypedAtomic} by definition). This sequence
1112     * also has cardinality zero-or-more, and may be shorter or longer than the
1113     * original.
1114     *<li>If the sequence is empty, the result column is assigned {@code NULL}
1115     * (or the column's default value, if one was specified). Otherwise, the
1116     * sequence is known to have length one or more, and:
1117     *<li>The spec does not say this (which may be an oversight or bug), but the
1118     * sequence must be checked for length greater than one, raising
1119     * {@code err:XPTY0004} in that case. The following steps require it to be a
1120     * singleton.
1121     *<li>It is labeled as a singleton sequence of {@code xs:anyAtomicType} and
1122     * used as input to an XQuery {@code cast as} expression. (Alternatively, it
1123     * could be labeled a one-or-more sequence of {@code xs:anyAtomicType},
1124     * leaving the length check to be done by {@code cast as}, which would raise
1125     * the same error {@code err:XPTY0004}, if longer than one.)
1126     *<li>The {@code cast as} is to the XQuery type determined as in
1127     * {@code determineXQueryFormalType} below, based on the SQL type of the
1128     * result column; or, if the SQL type is a date/time type with no time zone,
1129     * there is a first {@code cast as} to a specific XSD date/time type, which
1130     * is (if it has a time zone) first adjusted to UTC, then stripped of its
1131     * time zone, followed by a second {@code cast as} from that type to the one
1132     * determined from the result column type. Often, that will be the same type
1133     * as was used for the time zone adjustment, and the second {@code cast as}
1134     * will have nothing to do.
1135     *<li>The XQuery value resulting from the cast is converted and assigned to
1136     * the SQL-typed result column, a step with many details but few surprises,
1137     * therefore left for the morbidly curious to explore in the code. The flip
1138     * side of the time zone removal described above happens here: if the SQL
1139     * column type expects a time zone and the incoming value lacks one, it is
1140     * given a zone of UTC.
1141     *</ul>
1142     *<p>
1143     * The later steps above, those following the length-one check, are
1144     * handled by {@code xmlCastAsNonXML} below.
1145     *<p>
1146     * The earlier steps, from the start through the {@code XMLCAST} early steps
1147     * of document-node unwrapping, can all be applied by letting the original
1148     * result sequence be {@code $EXPR} in the expression:
1149     *<pre>
1150     * declare construction preserve;
1151     * data(document { $EXPR } / child::node())
1152     *</pre>
1153     * which may seem a bit of an anticlimax after seeing how many details lurk
1154     * behind those tidy lines of code.
1155     *<p>
1156     * <strong>About bare attribute nodes</strong>
1157     *<p>
1158     * One consequence of the rules above deserves special attention.
1159     * Consider something like:
1160     *<pre>
1161     * XMLTABLE('.' PASSING '&lt;a foo="bar"/&gt;' COLUMNS c1 VARCHAR PATH 'a/@foo');
1162     *</pre>
1163     *<p>
1164     * The result of the column expression is an XML attribute node all on its
1165     * own, with name {@code foo} and value {@code bar}, not enclosed in any
1166     * XML element. In the data type {@code XML(SEQUENCE)}, an attribute node
1167     * can appear standalone like that, but not in {@code XML(CONTENT)}.
1168     *<p>
1169     * Db2, Oracle, and even the XPath-based pseudo-XMLTABLE built into
1170     * PostgreSQL, will all accept that query and produce the result "bar".
1171     *<p>
1172     * However, a strict interpretation of the spec cannot produce that result,
1173     * because the result column type ({@code VARCHAR}) is not
1174     * {@code XML(SEQUENCE)}, meaning the result must be as if passed through
1175     * {@code XMLDOCUMENT(... RETURNING CONTENT)}, and the XQuery
1176     * {@code document { ... }} constructor is required to raise
1177     * {@code err:XPTY0004} upon encountering any bare attribute node. The
1178     * apparently common, convenient behavior of returning the attribute node's
1179     * value component is not, strictly, conformant.
1180     *<p>
1181     * This implementation will raise {@code err:XPTY0004}. That can be avoided
1182     * by simply wrapping any such bare attribute in {@code data()}:
1183     *<pre>
1184     * ... COLUMNS c1 VARCHAR PATH 'a/data(@foo)');
1185     *</pre>
1186     *<p>
1187     * It is possible the spec has an editorial mistake and did not intend to
1188     * require an error for this usage, in which case this implementation can
1189     * be changed to match a future clarification of the spec.
1190     */
1191    @Override
1192    public boolean assignRowValues(ResultSet receive, long currentRow)
1193    throws SQLException
1194    {
1195        if ( 0 == currentRow )
1196        {
1197            m_outBindings = new BindingsFromResultSet(receive, m_columnXQEs);
1198            int i = -1;
1199            AtomizingFunction atomizer = null;
1200            for ( Binding.Parameter p : m_outBindings )
1201            {
1202                SequenceType staticType = m_columnStaticTypes [ ++ i ];
1203                /*
1204                 * A null in m_columnXQEs identifies the ORDINALITY column,
1205                 * if any. Assign nothing to m_atomize[i], it won't be used.
1206                 */
1207                if ( null == m_columnXQEs [ i ] )
1208                    continue;
1209
1210                if ( Types.SQLXML == p.typeJDBC() )
1211                    continue;
1212
1213                /*
1214                 * Ok, the output column type is non-XML; choose an atomizer,
1215                 * either a simple identity if the result type is statically
1216                 * known to be zero-or-one atomic, or the long way through the
1217                 * general-purpose one. If the type is statically known to be
1218                 * the empty sequence (weird, but not impossible), the identity
1219                 * atomizer suffices and we're on to the next column.
1220                 */
1221                OccurrenceIndicator occur = staticType.getOccurrenceIndicator();
1222                if ( OccurrenceIndicator.ZERO == occur )
1223                {
1224                    m_atomize [ i ] = (v, col) -> v;
1225                    continue;
1226                }
1227
1228                /* So, it isn't known to be empty. If the column
1229                 * expression type isn't known to be atomic, or isn't known to
1230                 * be zero-or-one, then the general-purpose atomizer--a trip
1231                 * through data(document { ... } / child::node())--must be used.
1232                 * This atomizer will definitely produce a sequence of length
1233                 * zero or one, raising XPTY0004 otherwise. So the staticType
1234                 * can be replaced by xs:anyAtomicType?. xmlCastAsNonXML will
1235                 * therefore be passed xs:anyAtomicType, as in the spec.
1236                 *    BUT NO ... Saxon is more likely to find a converter from
1237                 * xs:untypedAtomic than from xs:anyAtomicType.
1238                 */
1239                ItemType itemType = staticType.getItemType();
1240                if ( occur.allowsMany()
1241                    || ! ItemType.ANY_ATOMIC_VALUE.subsumes(itemType)
1242                    /*
1243                     * The following tests may be punctilious to a fault. If we
1244                     * have a bare Saxon atomic type of either xs:base64Binary
1245                     * or xs:hexBinary type, Saxon will happily and successfully
1246                     * convert it to a binary string; but if we have the same
1247                     * thing as a less-statically-determinate type that we'll
1248                     * put through the atomizer, the conversion will fail unless
1249                     * its encoding matches the m_xmlbinary setting. That could
1250                     * seem weirdly unpredictable to a user, so we'll just
1251                     * (perversely) disallow the optimization (which would
1252                     * succeed) in the cases where the specified, unoptimized
1253                     * behavior would be to fail.
1254                     */
1255                    || ItemType.HEX_BINARY.subsumes(itemType)
1256                        && (XMLBinary.HEX != m_xmlbinary)
1257                    || ItemType.BASE64_BINARY.subsumes(itemType)
1258                        && (XMLBinary.BASE64 != m_xmlbinary)
1259                   )
1260                {
1261                    if ( null == atomizer )
1262                    {
1263                        XQueryEvaluator docWrapUnwrap = PredefinedQueryHolders
1264                            .DocumentWrapUnwrap.INSTANCE.load();
1265                        atomizer = (v, col) ->
1266                        {
1267                            docWrapUnwrap.setExternalVariable(
1268                                PredefinedQueryHolders.s_qEXPR, v);
1269                            v = docWrapUnwrap.evaluate();
1270                            /*
1271                             * It's already zero-or-one, or XPTY0004 was thrown
1272                             */
1273                            return v;
1274                        };
1275                    }
1276                    m_atomize [ i ] = atomizer;
1277                    /*
1278                     * The spec wants anyAtomicType below instead of
1279                     * untypedAtomic. But Saxon's getConverter is more likely
1280                     * to fail to find a converter from anyAtomicType to an
1281                     * arbitrary type, than from untypedAtomic. So use that.
1282                     */
1283                    m_columnStaticTypes [ i ] = s_01untypedAtomic;
1284                }
1285                else
1286                {
1287                    /*
1288                     * We know we'll be getting zero-or-one atomic value, so
1289                     * the atomizing function can be the identity.
1290                     */
1291                    m_atomize [ i ] = (v, col) -> v;
1292                }
1293            }
1294        }
1295
1296        if ( ! m_sequenceIterator.hasNext() )
1297            return false;
1298
1299        ++ currentRow; // for use as 1-based ordinality column
1300
1301        XdmItem it = m_sequenceIterator.next();
1302
1303        int i = 0;
1304        for ( Binding.Parameter p : m_outBindings )
1305        {
1306            XQueryEvaluator xqe = m_columnXQEs [ i ];
1307            AtomizingFunction atomizer = m_atomize [ i ];
1308            SequenceType staticType = m_columnStaticTypes [ i++ ];
1309
1310            if ( null == xqe )
1311            {
1312                receive.updateLong( i, currentRow);
1313                continue;
1314            }
1315
1316            try
1317            {
1318                xqe.setContextItem(it);
1319
1320                if ( null == atomizer ) /* => result type was found to be XML */
1321                {
1322                    receive.updateSQLXML(
1323                        i, returnContent(xqe.iterator(), false));
1324                    continue;
1325                }
1326
1327                XdmValue x1 = xqe.evaluate();
1328                x1 = atomizer.apply(x1, i);
1329
1330                /*
1331                 * The value is now known to be atomic and either exactly
1332                 * one or zero-or-one. May as well just use size() to see if
1333                 * it's empty.
1334                 */
1335                if ( 0 == x1.size() )
1336                {
1337                    receive.updateNull(i); // XXX Handle defaults some day
1338                    continue;
1339                }
1340                XdmAtomicValue av = (XdmAtomicValue)x1.itemAt(0);
1341                xmlCastAsNonXML(
1342                    av, staticType.getItemType(), p, receive, i, m_xmlbinary);
1343            }
1344            catch ( SaxonApiException | XPathException e )
1345            {
1346                throw new SQLException(e.getMessage(), "10000", e);
1347            }
1348        }
1349        return true;
1350    }
1351
1352    /**
1353     * Store the values of any passed parameters and/or context item into the
1354     * dynamic context, returning true if the overall query should
1355     * short-circuit and return null.
1356     *<p>
1357     * The specification requires the overall query to return null if a
1358     * context item is specified in the bindings and its value is null.
1359     * @param xqe XQuery evaluator into which to store the values.
1360     * @param passing The bindings whose values should be installed.
1361     * @param setContextItem True to handle the context item, if present in the
1362     * bindings. False to skip any processing of the context item, in cases
1363     * where the caller will handle that.
1364     * @return True if the overall query's return should be null, false if the
1365     * query should proceed to evaluation.
1366     */
1367    private static boolean storePassedValuesInDynamicContext(
1368        XQueryEvaluator xqe, Binding.Assemblage passing, boolean setContextItem)
1369        throws SQLException, SaxonApiException
1370    {
1371        /*
1372         * Is there or is there not a context item?
1373         */
1374        if ( ! setContextItem  ||  null == passing.contextItem() )
1375        {
1376            /* "... there is no context item in XDC." */
1377        }
1378        else
1379        {
1380            Object cve = passing.contextItem().valueJDBC();
1381            if ( null == cve )
1382                return true;
1383            XdmValue ci;
1384            if ( cve instanceof XdmNode ) // XXX support SEQUENCE input someday
1385            {
1386                ci = (XdmNode)cve;
1387            }
1388            else
1389                ci = xmlCastAsSequence(
1390                    cve, XMLBinary.HEX, passing.contextItem().typeXS());
1391            switch ( ci.size() )
1392            {
1393            case 0:
1394                /* "... there is no context item in XDC." */
1395                break;
1396            case 1:
1397                xqe.setContextItem(ci.itemAt(0));
1398                break;
1399            default:
1400                throw new SQLDataException(
1401                    "invalid XQuery context item", "2200V");
1402            }
1403        }
1404
1405        /*
1406         * For each <XML query variable> XQV:
1407         */
1408        for ( Binding.Parameter p : passing )
1409        {
1410            String name = p.name();
1411            Object v = p.valueJDBC();
1412            XdmValue vv;
1413            if ( null == v )
1414                vv = XdmEmptySequence.getInstance();
1415            else if ( v instanceof XdmNode ) // XXX support SEQUENCE someday
1416            {
1417                vv = (XdmNode)v;
1418            }
1419            else
1420                vv = xmlCastAsSequence(
1421                    v, XMLBinary.HEX, p.typeXS().getItemType());
1422            xqe.setExternalVariable(new QName(name), vv);
1423        }
1424
1425        return false;
1426    }
1427
1428    /**
1429     * Return a s9api {@link XQueryCompiler XQueryCompiler} with static context
1430     * preconfigured as the Syntax Rules dictate.
1431     * @param pt The single-row ResultSet representing the passed parameters
1432     * and context item, if any.
1433     * @param nameToIndex A Map, supplied empty, that on return will map
1434     * variable names for the dynamic context to column indices in {@code pt}.
1435     * If a context item was supplied, its index will be entered in the map
1436     * with the null key.
1437     */
1438    private static XQueryCompiler createStaticContextWithPassedTypes(
1439        Binding.Assemblage pt, Iterable<Map.Entry<String,String>> namespaces)
1440        throws SQLException, XPathException
1441    {
1442        XQueryCompiler xqc = s_s9p.newXQueryCompiler();
1443        xqc.declareNamespace(
1444            "sqlxml", "http://standards.iso.org/iso9075/2003/sqlxml");
1445        // https://sourceforge.net/p/saxon/mailman/message/20318550/ :
1446        xqc.declareNamespace("xdt", W3C_XML_SCHEMA_NS_URI);
1447
1448        for ( Map.Entry<String,String> e : namespaces )
1449            xqc.declareNamespace(e.getKey(), e.getValue());
1450
1451        /*
1452         * This business of predeclaring global external named variables
1453         * is not an s9api-level advertised ability in Saxon, hence the
1454         * various getUnderlying.../getStructured... methods here to access
1455         * the things that make it happen.
1456         */
1457        StaticQueryContext sqc = xqc.getUnderlyingStaticContext();
1458
1459        for ( Binding.Parameter p : pt )
1460        {
1461            String name = p.name();
1462            int ct = p.typeJDBC();
1463            assertCanCastAsXmlSequence(ct, name);
1464            SequenceType st = p.typeXS();
1465            sqc.declareGlobalVariable(
1466                new QName(name).getStructuredQName(),
1467                st.getUnderlyingSequenceType(), null, true);
1468        }
1469
1470        /*
1471         * Apply syntax rules to the context item, if any.
1472         */
1473        Binding.ContextItem ci = pt.contextItem();
1474        if ( null != ci )
1475        {
1476            int ct = ci.typeJDBC();
1477            assertCanCastAsXmlSequence(ct, "(context item)");
1478            ItemType it = ci.typeXS();
1479            xqc.setRequiredContextItemType(it);
1480        }
1481
1482        return xqc;
1483    }
1484
1485    /**
1486     * Check that something's type is "convertible to XML(SEQUENCE)
1487     * according to the Syntax Rules of ... <XML cast specification>."
1488     * That turns out not to be a very high bar; not much is excluded
1489     * by those rules except collection, row, structured, or
1490     * reference typed <value expression>s.
1491     * @param jdbcType The {@link Types JDBC type} to be checked.
1492     * @param what A string to include in the exception message if the
1493     * check fails.
1494     * @throws SQLException if {@code jdbcType} is one of the prohibited types.
1495     */
1496    private static void assertCanCastAsXmlSequence(int jdbcType, String what)
1497    throws SQLException
1498    {
1499        if ( Types.ARRAY == jdbcType || Types.STRUCT == jdbcType
1500            || Types.REF == jdbcType )
1501            throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
1502                "The type of \"" + what + "\" is not suitable for " +
1503                "XMLCAST to XML(SEQUENCE).", "42804");
1504    }
1505
1506    /**
1507     * The "determination of an XQuery formal type notation" algorithm.
1508     *<p>
1509     * This is relied on for parameters and context items passed to
1510     * {@code XMLQUERY} and therefore, {@code XMLTABLE} (and also, in the spec,
1511     * {@code XMLDOCUMENT} and {@code XMLPI}). Note that it does <em>not</em>
1512     * take an {@code XMLBinary} parameter, but rather imposes hexadecimal form
1513     * unconditionally, so in the contexts where this is called, any
1514     * {@code xmlbinary} setting is ignored.
1515     * @param b a {@code Binding} from which the JDBC type can be retrieved
1516     * @param forContextItem whether the type being derived is for a context
1517     * item or (if false) for a named parameter.
1518     * @return a {@code SequenceType} (always a singleton in the
1519     * {@code forContextItem} case)
1520     */
1521    private static SequenceType determineXQueryFormalType(
1522        Binding b, boolean forContextItem)
1523        throws SQLException
1524    {
1525        int sd = b.typeJDBC();
1526        OccurrenceIndicator suffix;
1527        /*
1528         * The SQL/XML standard uses a formal type notation straight out of
1529         * the XQuery 1.0 and XPath 2.0 Formal Semantics document, and that is
1530         * strictly more fine-grained and expressive than anything you can
1531         * actually say in the form of XQuery SequenceTypes. This method will
1532         * simply return the nearest approximation in the form of a sequence
1533         * type; some of the standard's distinct formal type notations will
1534         * collapse into the same SequenceType.
1535         *  That also means the various cases laid out in the standard will,
1536         * here, all simply assign some ItemType to 'it', and therefore the
1537         * tacking on of the occurrence suffix can be factored out for the
1538         * very end.
1539         */
1540        ItemType it;
1541
1542        if ( forContextItem )
1543            suffix = OccurrenceIndicator.ONE;
1544        // else if sd is XML(SEQUENCE) - we don't have this type yet
1545        //  suffix = OccurrenceIndicator.ZERO_OR_MORE;
1546        /*
1547         * Go through the motions of checking isNullable, though PL/Java's JDBC
1548         * currently hardcodes columnNullableUnknown. Maybe someday it won't.
1549         */
1550        else if ( b.knownNonNull() )
1551            suffix = OccurrenceIndicator.ONE;
1552        else
1553            suffix = OccurrenceIndicator.ZERO_OR_ONE;
1554
1555        // Define ET... for {DOCUMENT|CONTENT}(XMLSCHEMA) case ... not supported
1556
1557        // if SD is XML(DOCUMENT(UNTYPED)) - not currently tracked, can't tell
1558        //  it = s_itf.getDocumentTest(item type for xdt:untyped);
1559        // else if SD is XML(DOCUMENT(ANY)) - not currently tracked, can't tell
1560        //  it = s_itf.getDocumentTest(item type for xs:anyType);
1561        // else if SD is XML(DOCUMENT(XMLSCHEMA)) - unsupported and can't tell
1562        //  it = s_itf.getDocumentTest(the ET... we didn't define earlier)
1563        // else if SD is XML(CONTENT(UNTYPED)) - which we're not tracking ...
1564        //  at s9api granularity, there's no test for this that's not same as:
1565        // else if SD is XML(CONTENT(ANY)) - which we must assume for ANY XML
1566        if ( Types.SQLXML == sd )
1567            it = s_itf.getNodeKindTest(DOCUMENT);
1568        // else if SD is XML(CONTENT(XMLSCHEMA)) - we don't track and can't tell
1569        //  at s9api granularity, there's no test that means this anyway.
1570        // else if SD is XML(SEQUENCE) - we really should have this type, but no
1571        //  it = it.ANY_ITEM
1572        else // it ain't XML, it's some SQL type
1573        {
1574            ItemType xmlt = mapSQLDataTypeToXMLSchemaDataType(
1575                b, XMLBinary.HEX, Nulls.ABSENT);
1576            // ItemType pt = xmlt.getUnderlyingItemType().getPrimitiveType()
1577            //  .somehowGetFromUnderlyingPTBackToS9apiPT() - ugh, the hard part
1578            /*
1579             * The intention here is to replace any derived type with the
1580             * primitive type it is based on, *except* for three types that are
1581             * technically derived: integer (from decimal), yearMonthDuration
1582             * and dayTimeDuration (from duration). Those are not replaced, so
1583             * they stand, as if they were honorary primitive types.
1584             *
1585             * For now, it's simplified greatly by mapSQLDataType... skipping
1586             * the construction of a whole derived XML Schema snippet, and just
1587             * returning the type we want anyway. Also, no need to dive under
1588             * the s9api layer to try to make getPrimitiveType work.
1589             */
1590            it = xmlt;
1591        }
1592
1593        SequenceType xftn = makeSequenceType(it, suffix);
1594        return xftn;
1595    }
1596
1597    @SuppressWarnings("fallthrough")
1598    private static ItemType mapSQLDataTypeToXMLSchemaDataType(
1599        Binding b, XMLBinary xmlbinary, Nulls nulls)
1600        throws SQLException
1601    {
1602        /*
1603         * Nearly all of the fussing about specified in the standard
1604         * for this method is to create XML Schema derived types that
1605         * accurately reflect the typmod information for the SQL type
1606         * in question. Then, in determineXQueryFormalType (the only
1607         * client of this method so far!), all of that is thrown away
1608         * and our painstakingly specified derived type is replaced with
1609         * the primitive type we based it on. That simplifies a lot. :)
1610         * For now, forget the derived XML Schema declarations, and just
1611         * return the primitive types they would be based on.
1612         *
1613         * The need for the nulls parameter vanishes if no XML Schema snippets
1614         * are to be generated.
1615         *
1616         * If the full XML Schema snippet generation ever proves to be
1617         * needed, one hacky way to get it would be with a SELECT
1618         * query_to_xmlschema('SELECT null::type-in-question', false, false,
1619         * '') where the same derivations are already implemented (though it
1620         * produces some different results; that work may have been done from
1621         * an earlier version of the standard).
1622         */
1623        switch ( b.typeJDBC() )
1624        {
1625        case Types.CHAR:
1626        case Types.VARCHAR:
1627        case Types.CLOB:
1628            return ItemType.STRING;
1629
1630        case Types.BINARY:
1631        case Types.VARBINARY:
1632        case Types.BLOB:
1633            return XMLBinary.HEX == xmlbinary ?
1634                ItemType.HEX_BINARY : ItemType.BASE64_BINARY;
1635
1636        case Types.NUMERIC:
1637        case Types.DECIMAL:
1638            /*
1639             * Go through the motions to get the scale and do this right,
1640             * though PL/Java's getScale currently hardcodes a -1 return.
1641             * Maybe someday it won't.
1642             */
1643            int scale = b.scale();
1644            return 0 == scale ? ItemType.INTEGER : ItemType.DECIMAL;
1645
1646        case Types.INTEGER:
1647            return ItemType.INT;
1648        case Types.SMALLINT:
1649            return ItemType.SHORT;
1650        case Types.BIGINT:
1651            return ItemType.LONG;
1652
1653        case Types.REAL:
1654            return ItemType.FLOAT; // could check P, MINEXP, MAXEXP here.
1655        case Types.FLOAT:
1656            assert false; // PG should always report either REAL or DOUBLE
1657            /*FALLTHROUGH*/
1658        case Types.DOUBLE:
1659            return ItemType.DOUBLE;
1660
1661        case Types.BOOLEAN:
1662            return ItemType.BOOLEAN;
1663
1664        case Types.DATE:
1665            return ItemType.DATE;
1666
1667        case Types.TIME:
1668            return ItemType.TIME;
1669
1670        case Types.TIME_WITH_TIMEZONE:
1671            return ItemType.TIME; // restrictive facet would make sense here
1672
1673        case Types.TIMESTAMP:
1674            return ItemType.DATE_TIME;
1675
1676        case Types.TIMESTAMP_WITH_TIMEZONE:
1677            return ItemType.DATE_TIME_STAMP; // xsd 1.1 equivalent of facet!
1678
1679        // There's no JDBC Types.INTERVAL; handle it after switch
1680
1681        // Good luck finding out from JDBC if it's a domain
1682
1683        // PG doesn't have DISTINCT types per se
1684
1685        // PL/Java's JDBC doesn't support PostgreSQL's arrays as ARRAY
1686
1687        // PG doesn't seem to have multisets (JDBC doesn't grok them either)
1688
1689        // Types.SQLXML we could recognize, but for determineFormalTypes it has
1690        // been handled already, and it's not yet clear what would be
1691        // appropriate to return (short of the specified XMLSchema snippet),
1692        // probably just document.
1693
1694        // So punt all these for now; what hasn't been handled in this switch
1695        // can be handled specially after the switch falls through, and what
1696        // isn't, isn't supported just now.
1697        }
1698
1699        String typeName = b.typePG();
1700        if ( "interval".equals(typeName) )
1701        {
1702            /*
1703             * XXX This isn't right yet; it needs to be refined to a
1704             * YEAR_MONTH_DURATION or a DAY_TIME_DURATION in the appropriate
1705             * cases, and for that it needs access to the typmod information
1706             * for the type, which getColumnTypeName doesn't now provide.
1707             */
1708            return ItemType.DURATION;
1709        }
1710
1711        throw new SQLNonTransientException(String.format(
1712            "Mapping SQL type \"%s\" to XML type not supported", typeName),
1713            "0N000");
1714    }
1715
1716    /**
1717     * Implement that portion of the {@code <XML cast>} specification where
1718     * the target data type is sequence, and (for now, anyway) the source is
1719     * not an XML type; the only caller, so far, handles that case separately.
1720     * @param v The SQL value to be cast (in the form of an Object from JDBC).
1721     * @param enc Whether binary values should be encoded in hex or base 64.
1722     * @param xst The formal static XS type derived from the SQL type of v.
1723     * @return An {@code XdmValue}, {@code null} if {@code v} is null.
1724     */
1725    private static XdmValue xmlCastAsSequence(
1726        Object v, XMLBinary enc, ItemType xst)
1727        throws SQLException
1728    {
1729        if ( null == v )
1730            return null;
1731        /*
