1732         * What happens next in the standard is one of the most breathtaking
1733         * feats of obscurantism in the whole document. It begins, plausibly
1734         * enough, by using mapValuesOfSQLTypesToValuesOfXSTypes to produce
1735         * the lexical form of the XS type (but with XML metacharacters escaped,
1736         * if it's a string type). Then:
1737         * 1. That lexical form is to be fed to an XML parser, producing an
1738         *    XQuery document node that NEVER can be a well-formed document (it
1739         *    is expected to satisfy document { text ? } where the text node is
1740         *    just the lexical value form we started with, now with the escaped
1741         *    metacharacters unescaped again as a consequence of parsing). For
1742         *    some source types, mapValuesOfSQLTypesToValuesOfXSTypes can
1743         *    produce a string that parses to XML with element content: row
1744         *    types, arrays, multisets, XML. Clearly, those cases can't satisfy
1745         *    the formal type assumed here, and they are cases this routine
1746         *    won't be expected to handle: XML handled separately by the caller,
1747         *    arrays/structs/etc. being ruled out by assertCanCastAsXmlSequence.
1748         * 2. That document node is made the $TEMP parameter of an XML Query,
1749         *    '$TEMP cast as XSBTN' (where XSBTN is a QName for the result type
1750         *    chosen according to the rules) and the sequence resulting from
1751         *    that query is the result of the cast.
1752         *
1753         * Step (1) can only succeed if the XML parser doesn't insist on well-
1754         * formed documents, as the stock JRE parser emphatically does. And the
1755         * ultimate effect of that whole dance is that the cast in (2) casts a
1756         * document node to the target type, which means the document node gets
1757         * atomized, which, for a document node, means everything is thrown away
1758         * save the concatenated values of its descendant text nodes (or node,
1759         * in this case; haven't we seen that value somewhere before?), assigned
1760         * the type xs:untypedAtomic, and then that's operated on by the cast.
1761         *
1762         * Because this implementation's in PL/Java, the value v received here
1763         * has already been mapped from an SQL type to a Java type according to
1764         * JDBC's rules as PL/Java implements them, so there's one degree of
1765         * removal from the specified algorithm anyway. And the s9api
1766         * XdmAtomicValue already has constructors from several of the expected
1767         * Java types, as well as one taking a lexical form and explicit type.
1768         * Beause this is /example/ code, rather than slavishly implementing the
1769         * specified algorithm, it will assume that that is either roughly or
1770         * exactly equivalent to what these s9api constructors in fact do, and
1771         * just use them; conformance-testing code could then check for exact
1772         * equivalence if there's enough interest to write it.
1773         *
1774         * So, we will NOT start with this:
1775         *
1776         *   String xmlv = mapValuesOfSQLTypesToValuesOfXSTypes(
1777         *       v, enc, Nulls.ABSENT, true);
1778         *
1779         * Instead, we'll derive this type first ...
1780         */
1781        ItemType xsbt;
1782        // year-month interval type => xsbt = YEAR_MONTH_DURATION
1783        // day-time interval type => xsbt = DAY_TIME_DURATION
1784        xsbt = xst; // we have a winner!
1785        // xs non-built-in atomic type => xsbt = getPrimitiveType(ugh).
1786
1787        /*
1788         * ... and then use this method instead:
1789         */
1790        try
1791        {
1792            return mapJDBCofSQLvalueToXdmAtomicValue(v, enc, xsbt);
1793        }
1794        catch ( SaxonApiException | XPathException e )
1795        {
1796            throw new SQLException(e.getMessage(), "10000", e);
1797        }
1798    }
1799
1800    @FunctionalInterface
1801    interface CastingFunction
1802    {
1803        AtomicValue apply(AtomicValue v) throws XPathException;
1804    }
1805
1806    @FunctionalInterface
1807    interface CasterSupplier
1808    {
1809        CastingFunction get() throws SQLException, XPathException;
1810    }
1811
1812    @FunctionalInterface
1813    interface AtomizingFunction
1814    {
1815        /**
1816         * @param v sequence to be atomized
1817         * @param columnIndex only to include in exception if result has more
1818         * than one item
1819         */
1820        XdmValue apply(XdmValue v, int columnIndex)
1821        throws SaxonApiException, XPathException;
1822    }
1823
1824    private static XPathException noPrimitiveCast(ItemType vt, ItemType xt)
1825    {
1826        return new XPathException(
1827            "Casting from " + vt.getTypeName() + " to " + xt.getTypeName() +
1828            " can never succeed", "XPTY0004");
1829    }
1830
1831    /**
1832     * Handle the case of XMLCAST to a non-XML target type when the cast operand
1833     * is already a single atomic value.
1834     *<p>
1835     * The caller, if operating on a sequence, must itself handle the case of
1836     * an empty sequence (returning null, per General Rule 4c in :2011), or a
1837     * sequence of length greater than one (raising XPTY0004, which is not
1838     * specified in :2011, but the exclusion of such a sequence is implicit in
1839     * rules 4g and 4h; Db2 silently drops all but the first item, unlike
1840     * Oracle, which raises XPTY0004).
1841     * @param av The atomic operand value
1842     * @param p The parameter binding, recording the needed type information
1843     * @param rs ResultSet into which the value will be stored
1844     * @param col Index of the result column
1845     */
1846    private static void xmlCastAsNonXML(
1847        XdmAtomicValue av, ItemType vt,
1848        Binding.Parameter p, ResultSet rs, int col, XMLBinary enc)
1849        throws SQLException, XPathException
1850    {
1851        XdmAtomicValue bv;
1852        ItemType xt = p.typeXT(enc);
1853
1854        CastingFunction caster = p.atomicCaster(vt, () ->
1855        {
1856            ConversionRules rules = vt.getConversionRules();
1857            Converter c1;
1858            ItemType t1;
1859            Converter c2;
1860
1861            switch ( p.typeJDBC() )
1862            {
1863            case Types.TIMESTAMP:
1864                t1 = ItemType.DATE_TIME;
1865                break;
1866            case Types.TIME:
1867                t1 = ItemType.TIME;
1868                break;
1869            case Types.DATE:
1870                t1 = ItemType.DATE;
1871                break;
1872            default:
1873                c1 = rules.getConverter(
1874                    (AtomicType)vt.getUnderlyingItemType(),
1875                    (AtomicType)xt.getUnderlyingItemType());
1876                if ( null == c1 )
1877                    throw noPrimitiveCast(vt, xt);
1878                return (AtomicValue v) -> c1.convert(v).asAtomic();
1879            }
1880            /*
1881             * Nothing left here but the rest of the three date/timey cases
1882             * partly handled above.
1883             */
1884            c1 = rules.getConverter(
1885                (AtomicType)vt.getUnderlyingItemType(),
1886                (AtomicType)t1.getUnderlyingItemType());
1887            c2 = rules.getConverter(
1888                (AtomicType)t1.getUnderlyingItemType(),
1889                (AtomicType)xt.getUnderlyingItemType());
1890            if ( null == c1  ||  null == c2 )
1891                throw noPrimitiveCast(vt, xt);
1892            return (AtomicValue v) ->
1893            {
1894                v = c1.convert(v).asAtomic();
1895                v = ((CalendarValue)v).adjustTimezone(0).removeTimezone();
1896                return c2.convert(v).asAtomic();
1897            };
1898        });
1899
1900        bv = makeAtomicValue(caster.apply(av.getUnderlyingValue()));
1901
1902        if ( ItemType.STRING.subsumes(xt) )
1903            rs.updateString(col, bv.getStringValue());
1904
1905        else if ( ItemType.HEX_BINARY.subsumes(xt) )
1906            rs.updateBytes(col,
1907                ((HexBinaryValue)bv.getUnderlyingValue()).getBinaryValue());
1908        else if ( ItemType.BASE64_BINARY.subsumes(xt) )
1909            rs.updateBytes(col,
1910                ((Base64BinaryValue)bv.getUnderlyingValue()).getBinaryValue());
1911
1912        else if ( ItemType.DECIMAL.subsumes(xt) )
1913            rs.updateObject(col, bv.getValue());
1914
1915        /*
1916         * The standard calls for throwing "data exception - numeric value out
1917         * of range" rather than forwarding a float or double inf, -inf, or nan
1918         * to SQL, but PostgreSQL supports those values, and these conversions
1919         * preserve them.
1920         *  Because of the collapsing in typeXT(), xt will never be FLOAT,
1921         * only DOUBLE. JDBC is supposed to handle assigning a double to a float
1922         * column, anyway.
1923         */
1924        else if ( ItemType.DOUBLE.subsumes(xt) )
1925            rs.updateObject(col, bv.getValue());
1926
1927        else if ( ItemType.DATE.subsumes(xt) )
1928            rs.updateObject(col, bv.getLocalDate());
1929        else if ( ItemType.DATE_TIME.subsumes(xt) )
1930        {
1931            if ( ((CalendarValue)bv.getUnderlyingValue()).hasTimezone() )
1932                rs.updateObject(col, bv.getOffsetDateTime());
1933            else
1934            {
1935                LocalDateTime jv = bv.getLocalDateTime();
1936                rs.updateObject(col,
1937                    Types.TIMESTAMP_WITH_TIMEZONE == p.typeJDBC() ?
1938                        jv.atOffset(UTC) : jv);
1939            }
1940        }
1941        else if ( ItemType.TIME.subsumes(xt) ) // no handy tz/notz distinction
1942        {
1943            if ( ((CalendarValue)bv.getUnderlyingValue()).hasTimezone() )
1944                rs.updateObject(col, OffsetTime.parse(bv.getStringValue()));
1945            else
1946            {
1947                LocalTime jv = LocalTime.parse(bv.getStringValue());
1948                rs.updateObject(col,
1949                    Types.TIME_WITH_TIMEZONE == p.typeJDBC() ?
1950                        jv.atOffset(UTC) : jv);
1951            }
1952        }
1953
1954        else if ( ItemType.YEAR_MONTH_DURATION.subsumes(xt) )
1955            rs.updateString(col, toggleIntervalRepr(bv.getStringValue()));
1956        else if ( ItemType.DAY_TIME_DURATION.subsumes(xt) )
1957            rs.updateString(col, toggleIntervalRepr(bv.getStringValue()));
1958        else if ( ItemType.DURATION.subsumes(xt) ) // need this case for now
1959            rs.updateString(col, toggleIntervalRepr(bv.getStringValue()));
1960
1961        else if ( ItemType.BOOLEAN.subsumes(xt) )
1962            rs.updateObject(col, bv.getValue());
1963        else
1964            throw new SQLNonTransientException(String.format(
1965                "Mapping XML type \"%s\" to SQL value not supported", xt),
1966                "0N000");
1967    }
1968
1969    /**
1970     * Like the "Mapping values of SQL data types to values of XML Schema
1971     * data types" algorithm, except after the SQL values have already been
1972     * converted to Java values according to JDBC rules.
1973     *<p>
1974     * Also, this uses Saxon s9api constructors for the XML Schema values, which
1975     * accept the Java types directly. As a consequence, where the target type
1976     * {@code xst} is {@code xs:hexBinary} or {@code xs:base64Binary}, that type
1977     * will be produced, regardless of the passed {@code encoding}. This might
1978     * not be strictly correct, but is probably safest until an oddity in the
1979     * spec can be clarified: {@code determineXQueryFormalType} will always
1980     * declare {@code xs:hexBinary} as the type for an SQL byte string, and it
1981     * would violate type safety to construct a value here that honors the
1982     * {@code encoding} parameter but isn't of the declared formal type.
1983     */
1984    private static XdmAtomicValue mapJDBCofSQLvalueToXdmAtomicValue(
1985        Object dv, XMLBinary encoding, ItemType xst)
1986        throws SQLException, SaxonApiException, XPathException
1987    {
1988        if ( ItemType.STRING.equals(xst) )
1989            return new XdmAtomicValue((String)dv);
1990
1991        if ( ItemType.HEX_BINARY.equals(xst) )
1992            return makeAtomicValue(new HexBinaryValue((byte[])dv));
1993        if ( ItemType.BASE64_BINARY.equals(xst) )
1994            return makeAtomicValue(new Base64BinaryValue((byte[])dv));
1995
1996        if ( ItemType.INTEGER.equals(xst) )
1997            return new XdmAtomicValue(((BigInteger)dv).toString(), xst);
1998        if ( ItemType.DECIMAL.equals(xst) )
1999            return new XdmAtomicValue((BigDecimal)dv);
2000        if ( ItemType.INT.equals(xst) )
2001            return new XdmAtomicValue((Integer)dv);
2002        if ( ItemType.SHORT.equals(xst) )
2003            return new XdmAtomicValue((Short)dv);
2004        if ( ItemType.LONG.equals(xst) )
2005            return new XdmAtomicValue((Long)dv);
2006        if ( ItemType.FLOAT.equals(xst) )
2007            return new XdmAtomicValue((Float)dv);
2008        if ( ItemType.DOUBLE.equals(xst) )
2009            return new XdmAtomicValue((Double)dv);
2010
2011        if ( ItemType.BOOLEAN.equals(xst) )
2012            return new XdmAtomicValue((Boolean)dv);
2013
2014        if ( ItemType.DATE.equals(xst) )
2015        {
2016            if ( dv instanceof LocalDate )
2017                return new XdmAtomicValue((LocalDate)dv);
2018            return new XdmAtomicValue(dv.toString(), xst);
2019        }
2020
2021        if ( ItemType.TIME.equals(xst) )
2022            return new XdmAtomicValue(dv.toString(), xst);
2023
2024        if ( ItemType.DATE_TIME.equals(xst) )
2025        {
2026            if ( dv instanceof LocalDateTime )
2027                return new XdmAtomicValue((LocalDateTime)dv);
2028            return new XdmAtomicValue(dv.toString(), xst);
2029        }
2030
2031        if ( ItemType.DATE_TIME_STAMP.equals(xst) )
2032        {
2033            if ( dv instanceof OffsetDateTime )
2034                return new XdmAtomicValue((OffsetDateTime)dv);
2035            return new XdmAtomicValue(dv.toString(), xst);
2036        }
2037
2038        if ( ItemType.DURATION.equals(xst) )
2039            return new XdmAtomicValue(toggleIntervalRepr((String)dv), xst);
2040
2041        throw new SQLNonTransientException(String.format(
2042            "Mapping SQL value to XML type \"%s\" not supported", xst),
2043            "0N000");
2044    }
2045
2046    /*
2047     * Toggle the lexical representation of an interval/duration between the
2048     * form PostgreSQL likes and the form XML Schema likes. Only negative values
2049     * are affected. Positive values are returned unchanged, as are those that
2050     * don't fit any expected form; those will probably be reported as malformed
2051     * by whatever tries to consume them.
2052     */
2053    static String toggleIntervalRepr(String lex)
2054    {
2055        Matcher m = s_intervalSigns.matcher(lex);
2056        if ( ! m.matches() )
2057            return lex; // it's weird, just don't touch it
2058        if ( -1 == m.start(1) )
2059        {
2060            if ( -1 != m.start(2)  &&  -1 == m.start(3) ) // it's PG negative
2061                return '-' + lex.replace("-", "");        // make it XS negative
2062        }
2063        else if ( -1 == m.start(2)  &&  -1 != m.start(3) )// it's XS negative
2064            return m.usePattern(s_intervalSignSite)       // make it PG negative
2065                .reset(lex.substring(1)).replaceAll("-");
2066        return lex; // it's either positive, or weird, just don't touch it
2067    }
2068
2069    static Iterable<Map.Entry<String,String>> namespaceBindings(String[] nbs)
2070    throws SQLException
2071    {
2072        if ( 1 == nbs.length % 2 )
2073            throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
2074                "Namespace binding array must have even length", "42000");
2075        Map<String,String> m = new HashMap<>();
2076
2077        for ( int i = 0; i < nbs.length; i += 2 )
2078        {
2079            String prefix = nbs[i];
2080            String uri = nbs[1 + i];
2081
2082            if ( null == prefix  ||  null == uri )
2083                throw new SQLDataException(
2084                    "Namespace binding array elements must not be null",
2085                    "22004");
2086
2087            if ( ! "".equals(prefix) )
2088            {
2089                if ( ! isValidNCName(prefix) )
2090                    throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
2091                        "Not an XML NCname: \"" + prefix + '"', "42602");
2092                if ( XML_NS_PREFIX.equals(prefix)
2093                    || XMLNS_ATTRIBUTE.equals(prefix) )
2094                    throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
2095                        "Namespace prefix may not be xml or xmlns", "42939");
2096                if ( XML_NS_URI.equals(uri)
2097                    || XMLNS_ATTRIBUTE_NS_URI.equals(uri) )
2098                    throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
2099                        "Namespace URI has a disallowed value", "42P17");
2100                if ( "".equals(uri) )
2101                    throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
2102                        "URI for non-default namespace may not be zero-length",
2103                        "42P17");
2104            }
2105
2106            String was = m.put(prefix.intern(), uri.intern());
2107
2108            if ( null != was )
2109                throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
2110                    "Namespace prefix \"" + prefix + "\" multiply bound (" +
2111                    "to \"" + was + "\" and \"" + uri + "\")", "42712");
2112        }
2113
2114        return Collections.unmodifiableSet(m.entrySet());
2115    }
2116
2117    static class Binding
2118    {
2119        String typePG() throws SQLException
2120        {
2121            if ( null != m_typePG )
2122                return m_typePG;
2123            return m_typePG = implTypePG();
2124        }
2125
2126        int typeJDBC() throws SQLException
2127        {
2128            if ( null != m_typeJDBC )
2129                return m_typeJDBC;
2130            int tj = implTypeJDBC();
2131            /*
2132             * The JDBC types TIME_WITH_TIMEZONE and TIMESTAMP_WITH_TIMEZONE
2133             * first appear in JDBC 4.2 / Java 8. PL/Java's JDBC driver does
2134             * not yet return those values. As a workaround until it does,
2135             * recheck here using the PG type name string, if TIME or TIMESTAMP
2136             * is the JDBC type that the driver returned.
2137             *
2138             * Also for backward compatibility, the driver still returns
2139             * Types.OTHER for XML, rather than Types.SQLXML. Check and fix that
2140             * here too.
2141             */
2142            switch ( tj )
2143            {
2144            case Types.OTHER:
2145                if ( "xml".equals(typePG()) )
2146                    tj = Types.SQLXML;
2147                break;
2148            case Types.TIME:
2149                if ( "timetz".equals(typePG()) )
2150                    tj = Types.TIME_WITH_TIMEZONE;
2151                break;
2152            case Types.TIMESTAMP:
2153                if ( "timestamptz".equals(typePG()) )
2154                    tj = Types.TIMESTAMP_WITH_TIMEZONE;
2155                break;
2156            default:
2157            }
2158            return m_typeJDBC = tj;
2159        }
2160
2161        Object valueJDBC() throws SQLException
2162        {
2163            if ( m_valueJDBCValid )
2164                return m_valueJDBC;
2165            /*
2166             * When JDBC 4.2 added support for the JSR 310 date/time types, for
2167             * back-compatibility purposes, it did not change what types a plain
2168             * getObject(...) would return for them, which could break existing
2169             * code. Instead, it's necessary to use the form of getObject that
2170             * takes a Class<?>, and ask for the new classes explicitly.
2171             *
2172             * Similarly, PL/Java up through 1.5.0 has always returned a String
2173             * from getObject for a PostgreSQL xml type. Here, the JDBC standard
2174             * provides that a SQLXML object should be returned, and that should
2175             * happen in a future major PL/Java release, but for now, the plain
2176             * getObject will still return String, so it is also necessary to
2177             * ask for the SQLXML type explicitly. In fact, we will ask for
2178             * XdmNode, as it might be referred to more than once (if a
2179             * parameter), and a SQLXML can't be read more than once, nor would
2180             * there be any sense in building an XdmNode from it more than once.
2181             */
2182            switch ( typeJDBC() )
2183            {
2184            case Types.DATE:
2185                return setValueJDBC(implValueJDBC(LocalDate.class));
2186            case Types.TIME:
2187                return setValueJDBC(implValueJDBC(LocalTime.class));
2188            case Types.TIME_WITH_TIMEZONE:
2189                return setValueJDBC(implValueJDBC(OffsetTime.class));
2190            case Types.TIMESTAMP:
2191                return setValueJDBC(implValueJDBC(LocalDateTime.class));
2192            case Types.TIMESTAMP_WITH_TIMEZONE:
2193                return setValueJDBC(implValueJDBC(OffsetDateTime.class));
2194            case Types.SQLXML:
2195                return setValueJDBC(implValueJDBC(XdmNode.class));
2196            default:
2197            }
2198            return setValueJDBC(implValueJDBC());
2199        }
2200
2201        boolean knownNonNull() throws SQLException
2202        {
2203            if ( null != m_knownNonNull )
2204                return m_knownNonNull;
2205            return m_knownNonNull = implKnownNonNull();
2206        }
2207
2208        int scale() throws SQLException
2209        {
2210            if ( null != m_scale )
2211                return m_scale;
2212            return m_scale = implScale();
2213        }
2214
2215        static class ContextItem extends Binding
2216        {
2217            /**
2218             * Return the XML Schema type of this input binding for a context
2219             * item.
2220             *<p>
2221             * Because it is based on {@code determinXQueryFormalType}, this
2222             * method is not parameterized by {@code XMLBinary}, and will always
2223             * map a binary-string SQL type to {@code xs:hexBinary}.
2224             */
2225            ItemType typeXS() throws SQLException
2226            {
2227                if ( null != m_typeXS )
2228                    return m_typeXS;
2229                SequenceType st = implTypeXS(true);
2230                assert OccurrenceIndicator.ONE == st.getOccurrenceIndicator();
2231                return m_typeXS = st.getItemType();
2232            }
2233
2234            protected ItemType m_typeXS;
2235        }
2236
2237        static class Parameter extends Binding
2238        {
2239            String name()
2240            {
2241                return m_name;
2242            }
2243
2244            SequenceType typeXS() throws SQLException
2245            {
2246                if ( null != m_typeXS )
2247                    return m_typeXS;
2248                return m_typeXS = implTypeXS(false);
2249            }
2250
2251            /**
2252             * Return the XML Schema type collapsed according to the Syntax Rule
2253             * deriving {@code XT} for {@code XMLCAST}.
2254             *<p>
2255             * The intent of the rule is unclear, but it involves collapsing
2256             * certain sets of more-specific types that {@code typeXS} might
2257             * return into common supertypes, for use only in an intermediate
2258             * step of {@code xmlCastAsNonXML}. Unlike {@code typeXS}, this
2259             * method must be passed an {@code XMLBinary} parameter reflecting
2260             * the hex/base64 choice currently in scope.
2261             * @param enc whether to use {@code xs:hexBinary} or
2262             * {@code xs:base64Binary} as the XML Schema type corresponding to a
2263             * binary-string SQL type.
2264             */
2265            ItemType typeXT(XMLBinary enc) throws SQLException
2266            {
2267                throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
2268                    "typeXT() on synthetic binding");
2269            }
2270
2271            /**
2272             * Memoize and return a casting function from a given
2273             * {@code ItemType} to the type of this parameter.
2274             *<p>
2275             * Used only by {@code xmlCastAsNonXML}, which does all the work
2276             * of constructing the function; this merely allows it to be
2277             * remembered, if many casts to the same output parameter will be
2278             * made (as by {@code xmltable}).
2279             */
2280            CastingFunction atomicCaster(ItemType it, CasterSupplier s)
2281            throws SQLException, XPathException
2282            {
2283                throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
2284                    "atomicCaster() on synthetic binding");
2285            }
2286
2287            protected SequenceType m_typeXS;
2288
2289            private final String m_name;
2290
2291            /**
2292             * @param name The SQL name of the parameter
2293             * @param checkName True if the name must be a valid NCName (as for
2294             * an input parameter from SQL to the XML query context), or false
2295             * if the name doesn't matter (as when it describes a result, or the
2296             * sole input value of an XMLCAST.
2297             * @throws SQLException if the name of a checked input parameter
2298             * isn't a valid NCName.
2299             */
2300            protected Parameter(String name, boolean checkName)
2301            throws SQLException
2302            {
2303                if ( checkName  &&  ! isValidNCName(name) )
2304                    throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
2305                        "Not an XML NCname: \"" + name + '"', "42602");
2306                m_name = name;
2307            }
2308        }
2309
2310        protected String m_typePG;
2311        protected Integer m_typeJDBC;
2312        protected Boolean m_knownNonNull;
2313        protected Integer m_scale;
2314        private Object m_valueJDBC;
2315        private boolean m_valueJDBCValid;
2316        protected Object setValueJDBC(Object v)
2317        {
2318            m_valueJDBCValid = true;
2319            return m_valueJDBC = v;
2320        }
2321

2323        {
2324            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
2325                "typePG() on synthetic binding");
2326        }

2329        {
2330            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
2331                "typeJDBC() on synthetic binding");
2332        }

2335        {
2336            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
2337                "knownNonNull() on synthetic binding");
2338        }

2341        {
2342            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
2343                "scale() on synthetic binding");
2344        }

2347        {
2348            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
2349                "valueJDBC() on synthetic binding");

2352        /*
2353         * This implementation just forwards to the type-less version, then
2354         * fails if that did not return the wanted type. Override if a smarter
2355         * behavior is possible.
2356         */
2357        protected <T> T implValueJDBC(Class<T> type) throws SQLException
2358        {
2359            return type.cast(implValueJDBC());
2360        }

2363        throws SQLException
2364        {
2365            return determineXQueryFormalType(this, forContextItem);

2368        static class Assemblage implements Iterable<Parameter>
2369        {
2370            ContextItem contextItem() { return m_contextItem; }
2371
2372            @Override
2373            public Iterator<Parameter> iterator()
2374            {
2375                return m_params.iterator();

2379            protected Collection<Parameter> m_params = Collections.emptyList();
2380        }

2382
2383    static class BindingsFromResultSet extends Binding.Assemblage
2384    {
2385        /**
2386         * Construct the bindings from a ResultSet representing input parameters
2387         * to an XML query.
2388         * @param rs ResultSet representing the input parameters. Column names
2389         * "." and "?COLUMN?" are treated specially, and used to supply the
2390         * query's context item; every other column name must be a valid NCName,
2391         * and neither any named parameter nor the context item may be mentioned
2392         * more than once.
2393         * @param checkNames True if the input parameter names matter (a name of
2394         * "." or "?COLUMN?" will define the context item, and any other name
2395         * must be a valid NCName); false to skip such checking (as for the
2396         * single input value to XMLCAST, whose name doesn't matter).
2397         * @throws SQLException if names are duplicated or invalid.
2398         */
2399        BindingsFromResultSet(ResultSet rs, boolean checkNames)
2400        throws SQLException
2401        {
2402            m_resultSet = rs;
2403            m_rsmd = rs.getMetaData();
2404
2405            int nParams = m_rsmd.getColumnCount();
2406            ContextItem contextItem = null;
2407            Map<String,Binding.Parameter> n2b = new HashMap<>();
2408
2409            if ( 0 < nParams )
2410                m_dBuilder = s_s9p.newDocumentBuilder();
2411
2412            for ( int i = 1; i <= nParams; ++i )
2413            {
2414                String label = m_rsmd.getColumnLabel(i);
2415                if ( checkNames  &&
2416                    ("?COLUMN?".equals(label)  ||  ".".equals(label)) )
2417                {
2418                    if ( null != contextItem )
2419                    throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
2420                        "Context item supplied more than once (at " +
2421                        contextItem.m_idx + " and " + i + ')', "42712");
2422                    contextItem = new ContextItem(i);
2423                    continue;
2424                }
2425
2426                Parameter was =
2427                    (Parameter)n2b.put(
2428                        label, new Parameter(label, i, checkNames));
2429                if ( null != was )
2430                    throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
2431                        "Name \"" + label + "\" duplicated at positions " +
2432                        was.m_idx + " and " + i, "42712");
2433            }
2434
2435            m_contextItem = contextItem;
2436            m_params = n2b.values();
2437        }
2438
2439        /**
2440         * Construct the bindings from a ResultSet representing output
2441         * parameters (as from XMLTABLE).
2442         * @param rs ResultSet representing the result parameters. Names have
2443         * no particular significance and are not subject to any checks.
2444         * @param exprs Compiled evaluators for the supplied column expressions.
2445         * The number of these must match the number of columns in {@code rs}.
2446         * One of these (and no more than one; the caller will have enforced
2447         * that) is allowed to be null, making the corresponding column
2448         * "FOR ORDINALITY". An ordinality column will be checked to ensure it
2449         * has an SQL type that is (ahem) "exact numeric with scale 0 (zero)."
2450         * May be null if this is some other general-purpose output result set,
2451         * not for an XMLTABLE.
2452         * @throws SQLException if numbers of columns and expressions don't
2453         * match, or there is an ordinality column and its type is not suitable.
2454         */
2455        @SuppressWarnings("fallthrough")
2456        BindingsFromResultSet(ResultSet rs, XQueryEvaluator[] exprs)
2457        throws SQLException
2458        {
2459            m_resultSet = rs;
2460            m_rsmd = rs.getMetaData();
2461
2462            int nParams = m_rsmd.getColumnCount();
2463            if ( null != exprs  &&  nParams != exprs.length )
2464                throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
2465                    "Not as many supplied column expressions as output columns",
2466                    "42611");
2467
2468            Binding.Parameter[] ps = new Binding.Parameter[ nParams ];
2469
2470            for ( int i = 1; i <= nParams; ++i )
2471            {
2472                String label = m_rsmd.getColumnLabel(i);
2473                Parameter p = new Parameter(label, i, false);
2474                ps [ i - 1 ] = p;
2475                if ( null != exprs  &&  null == exprs [ i - 1 ] )
2476                {
2477                    switch ( p.typeJDBC() )
2478                    {
2479                    case Types.INTEGER:
2480                    case Types.SMALLINT:
2481                    case Types.BIGINT:
2482                        break;
2483                    case Types.NUMERIC:
2484                    case Types.DECIMAL:
2485                        int scale = p.scale();
2486                        if ( 0 == scale  ||  -1 == scale )
2487                            break;
2488                        /*FALLTHROUGH*/
2489                    default:
2490                        throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
2491                            "Column FOR ORDINALITY must have an exact numeric" +
2492                            " type with scale zero.", "42611");
2493                    }
2494                }
2495            }
2496
2497            m_params = asList(ps);
2498        }
2499
2500        private ResultSet m_resultSet;
2501        private ResultSetMetaData m_rsmd;
2502        DocumentBuilder m_dBuilder;
2503
2504        <T> T typedValueAtIndex(int idx, Class<T> type) throws SQLException
2505        {
2506            if ( XdmNode.class != type )
2507                return m_resultSet.getObject(idx, type);
2508            try
2509            {
2510                SQLXML sx = m_resultSet.getObject(idx, SQLXML.class);
2511                return type.cast(
2512                    m_dBuilder.build(sx.getSource((Class<Source>)null)));
2513            }
2514            catch ( SaxonApiException e )
2515            {
2516                throw new SQLException(e.getMessage(), "10000", e);
2517            }
2518        }
2519
2520        class ContextItem extends Binding.ContextItem
2521        {
2522            final int m_idx;
2523
2524            ContextItem(int index) { m_idx = index; }
2525
2526            protected String implTypePG() throws SQLException
2527            {
2528                return m_rsmd.getColumnTypeName(m_idx);
2529            }
2530
2531            protected int implTypeJDBC() throws SQLException
2532            {
2533                return m_rsmd.getColumnType(m_idx);
2534            }
2535
2536            protected int implScale() throws SQLException
2537            {
2538                return m_rsmd.getScale(m_idx);
2539            }
2540
2541            protected Object implValueJDBC() throws SQLException
2542            {
2543                return m_resultSet.getObject(m_idx);
2544            }
2545
2546            protected <T> T implValueJDBC(Class<T> type) throws SQLException
2547            {
2548                return typedValueAtIndex(m_idx, type);
2549            }
2550        }
2551
2552        class Parameter extends Binding.Parameter
2553        {
2554            final int m_idx;
2555            private ItemType m_typeXT;
2556            private CastingFunction m_atomCaster;
2557            private ItemType m_lastCastFrom;
2558
2559            Parameter(String name, int index, boolean isInput)
2560            throws SQLException
2561            {
2562                super(name, isInput);
2563                m_idx = index;
2564            }
2565
2566            @Override
2567            ItemType typeXT(XMLBinary enc) throws SQLException
2568            {
2569                if ( null != m_typeXT )
2570                    return m_typeXT;
2571
2572                ItemType it =
2573                    mapSQLDataTypeToXMLSchemaDataType(this, enc, Nulls.ABSENT);
2574                if ( ! ItemType.ANY_ATOMIC_VALUE.subsumes(it) )
2575                    return m_typeXT = it;
2576
2577                if ( it.equals(ItemType.INTEGER) )
2578                {
2579                    int tj = typeJDBC();
2580                    if ( Types.NUMERIC == tj || Types.DECIMAL == tj )
2581                        it = ItemType.DECIMAL;
2582                }
2583                else if ( ItemType.INTEGER.subsumes(it) )
2584                    it = ItemType.INTEGER;
2585                else if ( ItemType.FLOAT.subsumes(it) )
2586                    it = ItemType.DOUBLE;
2587                else if ( ItemType.DATE_TIME_STAMP.subsumes(it) )
2588                    it = ItemType.DATE_TIME;
2589
2590                return m_typeXT = it;
2591            }
2592
2593            @Override
2594            CastingFunction atomicCaster(ItemType it, CasterSupplier s)
2595            throws SQLException, XPathException
2596            {
2597                if ( null == m_atomCaster || ! it.equals(m_lastCastFrom) )
2598                {
2599                    m_atomCaster = s.get();
2600                    m_lastCastFrom = it;
2601                }
2602                return m_atomCaster;
2603            }
2604
2605            protected String implTypePG() throws SQLException
2606            {
2607                return m_rsmd.getColumnTypeName(m_idx);
2608            }
2609
2610            protected int implTypeJDBC() throws SQLException
2611            {
2612                return m_rsmd.getColumnType(m_idx);
2613            }
2614
2615            protected boolean implKnownNonNull() throws SQLException
2616            {
2617                return columnNoNulls == m_rsmd.isNullable(m_idx);
2618            }
2619
2620            protected int implScale() throws SQLException
2621            {
2622                return m_rsmd.getScale(m_idx);
2623            }
2624
2625            protected Object implValueJDBC() throws SQLException
2626            {
2627                return m_resultSet.getObject(m_idx);
2628            }
2629
2630            protected <T> T implValueJDBC(Class<T> type) throws SQLException
2631            {
2632                return typedValueAtIndex(m_idx, type);
2633            }
2634        }
2635    }
2636
2637    static class BindingsFromXQX extends Binding.Assemblage
2638    {
2639        /**
2640         * Construct a new assemblage of bindings for the static context of an
2641         * XMLTABLE column expression. It will have the same named-parameter
2642         * bindings passed to the row expression, but the static type of the
2643         * context item will be the result type of the row expression. The
2644         * {@code ContextItem} in this assemblage will have no associated value;
2645         * the caller is responsible for retrieving that from the row evaluator
2646         * and storing it in the column expression context every iteration.
2647         * @param xqx The result of compiling the row expression; its
2648         * compiler-determined static result type will be used as the static
2649         * context item type.
2650         * @param params The bindings supplied to the row expression. Its named
2651         * parameters will be copied as the named parameters here.
2652         */
2653        BindingsFromXQX(XQueryExecutable xqx, Binding.Assemblage params)
2654        {
2655            m_params = params.m_params;
2656            m_contextItem = new ContextItem(xqx.getResultItemType());
2657        }
2658
2659        static class ContextItem extends Binding.ContextItem
2660        {
2661            ContextItem(ItemType it)
2662            {
2663                m_typeXS = it;
2664                /*
2665                 * There needs to be a dummy JDBC type to return when queried
2666                 * for purposes of assertCanCastAsXmlSequence. It can literally
2667                 * be any type outside of the few that method rejects. Because
2668                 * the XS type is already known, nothing else will need to ask
2669                 * for this, or care.
2670                 */
2671                m_typeJDBC = Types.OTHER;
2672            }
2673        }
2674    }
2675
2676    /*
2677     * The XQuery-regular-expression-based functions added in 9075-2:2006.
2678     *
2679     * For each function below, a parameter is marked //strict if the spec
2680     * explicitly says the result is NULL when that parameter is NULL. The
2681     * parameters not marked //strict (including the non-standard w3cNewlines
2682     * added here) all have non-null defaults, so by executive decision, these
2683     * functions will all get the onNullInput=RETURNS_NULL treatment, so none of
2684     * the null-checking has to be done here. At worst, that may result in a
2685     * mystery NULL return rather than an error, if someone explicitly passes
2686     * NULL to one of the parameters with a non-null default.
2687     */
2688
2689    /*
2690     * Check valid range of 'from' and supported 'usingOctets'.
2691     *
2692     * Every specified function that has a start position FROM and a USING
2693     * clause starts with a check that the start position is in range. This
2694     * function factors out that test, returning true if the start position is
2695     * /out of range/ (triggering the caller to return the special result
2696     * defined for that case), returning false if the value is in range, or
2697     * throwing an exception if the length unit specified in the USING clause
2698     * isn't supported.
2699     */
2700    private static boolean usingAndLengthCheck(
2701        String in, int from, boolean usingOctets, String function)
2702    throws SQLException
2703    {
2704        if ( usingOctets )
2705            throw new SQLFeatureNotSupportedException(
2706                '"' + function + "\" does not yet support USING OCTETS",
2707                "0A000");
2708        return ( 1 > from  ||  from > getStringLength(in) );
2709    }
2710
2711    private static void newlinesCheck(boolean w3cNewlines, String function)
2712    throws SQLException
2713    {
2714        if ( ! w3cNewlines )
2715            throw new SQLFeatureNotSupportedException(
2716                '"' + function + "\" does not yet support the ISO SQL newline" +
2717                " conventions, only the original W3C XQuery ones" +
2718                " (HINT: pass w3cNewlines => true)", "0A000");
2719    }
2720
2721    private static RegularExpression compileRE(String pattern, String flags)
2722    throws SQLException
2723    {
2724        try
2725        {
2726            return s_s9p.getUnderlyingConfiguration()
2727                .compileRegularExpression(pattern, flags, "XP30", null);
2728        }
2729        catch ( XPathException e )
2730        {
2731            if ( NamespaceConstant.ERR.equals(e.getErrorCodeNamespace()) )
2732            {
2733                if ( "FORX0001".equals(e.getErrorCodeLocalPart()) )
2734                    throw new SQLDataException(
2735                        "invalid XQuery option flag", "2201T", e);
2736                if ( "FORX0002".equals(e.getErrorCodeLocalPart()) )
2737                    throw new SQLDataException(
2738                        "invalid XQuery regular expression", "2201S", e);
2739            }
2740            throw new SQLException(
2741                "compiling XQuery regular expression: " + e.getMessage(), e);
2742        }
2743    }
2744
2745    private static CharSequence replace(
2746        RegularExpression re, CharSequence in, CharSequence with)
2747        throws SQLException
2748    {
2749        /*
2750         * Report the standard-mandated error if replacing a zero-length match.
2751         * Strictly speaking, this is a test of the length of the match, not of
2752         * the input string. Here, though, this private method is only called by
2753         * translate_regex, which always passes only the portion of the input
2754         * string that matched, so the test is equivalent.
2755         *  As to why the SQL committee would make such a point of disallowing
2756         * replacement of a zero-length match, that's a good question. See
2757         * s_intervalSignSite in this very file for an example where replacing
2758         * a zero-length match is just what's wanted. (But that pattern relies
2759         * on lookahead/lookbehind operators, which XQuery regular expressions
2760         * don't have.)
2761         *  When the underlying library is Saxon, there is an Easter egg: if a
2762         * regular expression is compiled with a 'flags' string ending in ";j",
2763         * a Java regular expression is produced instead of an XQuery one (with
2764         * standards conformance cast to the wind). That can be detected with
2765         * getFlags() on the regular expression: not looking for ";j", because
2766         * that has been stripped out, but for "d" which is a Java regex flag
2767         * that Saxon sets by default, and is not a valid XQuery regex flag.
2768         *  If the caller has used Saxon's Easter egg to get a Java regex, here
2769         * is another Easter egg to go with it, allowing zero-length matches
2770         * to be replaced if that's what the caller wants to do.
2771         */
2772        if ( 0 == in.length()  &&  ! re.getFlags().contains("d") )
2773            throw new SQLDataException(
2774                "attempt to replace a zero-length string", "2201U");
2775        try
2776        {
2777            return re.replace(in, with);
2778        }
2779        catch ( XPathException e )
2780        {
2781            if ( NamespaceConstant.ERR.equals(e.getErrorCodeNamespace()) )
2782            {
2783                if ( "FORX0003".equals(e.getErrorCodeLocalPart()) )
2784                    throw new SQLDataException(
2785                        "attempt to replace a zero-length string", "2201U", e);
2786                if ( "FORX0004".equals(e.getErrorCodeLocalPart()) )
2787                    throw new SQLDataException(
2788                        "invalid XQuery replacement string", "2201V", e);
2789            }
2790            throw new SQLException(
2791                "replacing regular expression match: " + e.getMessage(), e);
2792        }
2793    }
2794
2795    interface MatchVector
2796    {
2797        int groups();
2798        int position(int group);
2799        int length(int group);
2800    }
2801
2802    interface ListOfMatchVectors
2803    {
2804        /**
2805         * Return the MatchVector for one occurrence of a match.
2806         *<p>
2807         * Any previously-returned MatchVector is invalid after another get.
2808         * In multiple calls to get, the occurrence parameter must be strictly
2809         * increasing.
2810         * After get has returned null, it should not be called again.
2811         */
2812        MatchVector get(int occurrence) throws SQLException;
2813        void close();
2814    }
2815
2816    static class LOMV
2817    implements ListOfMatchVectors, MatchVector, RegexIterator.MatchHandler
2818    {
2819        private RegexIterator m_ri;
2820        private int m_pos;
2821        private int m_occurrence;
2822
2823        LOMV(int startPos, RegexIterator ri)
2824        {
2825            m_ri = ri;
2826            m_pos = startPos;
2827        }
2828
2829        static ListOfMatchVectors of(
2830            String pattern, String flags, String in, int from)
2831            throws SQLException
2832        {
2833            RegularExpression re = compileRE(pattern, flags);
2834            return of(re, in, from);
2835        }
2836
2837        static ListOfMatchVectors of(RegularExpression re, String in, int from)
2838        {
2839            RegexIterator ri =
2840                re.analyze(in.substring(in.offsetByCodePoints(0, from - 1)));
2841            return new LOMV(from, ri);
2842        }
2843
2844        private int[] m_begPositions;
2845        private int[] m_endPositions;
2846
2847        @Override // ListOfMatchVectors
2848        public MatchVector get(int occurrence) throws SQLException
2849        {
2850            try
2851            {
2852                StringValue sv;
2853                for ( ;; )
2854                {
2855                    sv = m_ri.next();
2856                    if ( null == sv )
2857                        return null;
2858                    if ( m_ri.isMatching() )
2859                        if ( ++ m_occurrence == occurrence )
2860                            break;
2861                    m_pos += sv.getStringLength();
2862                }
2863
2864                if ( null == m_begPositions )
2865                {
2866                    int groups = m_ri.getNumberOfGroups();
2867                    /*
2868                     * Saxon's Apache-derived XQuery engine will report a number
2869                     * of groups counting $0 (so it will be 1 even if no capture
2870                     * groups were defined in the expression). In contrast, the
2871                     * Java regex engine that you get with the Saxon ";j" Easter
2872                     * egg does not count $0 (so arrays need groups+1 entries).
2873                     * It's hard to tell from here which flavor was used, plus
2874                     * the Saxon behavior might change some day, so just spend
2875                     * the extra + 1 every time.
2876                     */
2877                    m_begPositions = new int [ groups + 1 ];
2878                    m_endPositions = new int [ groups + 1 ];
2879                }
2880
2881                m_begPositions [ 0 ] = m_pos;
2882
2883                fill(m_begPositions, 1, m_begPositions.length, 0);
2884                fill(m_endPositions, 1, m_endPositions.length, 0);
2885                m_ri.processMatchingSubstring(this);
2886
2887                m_endPositions [ 0 ] = m_pos;
2888
2889                return this;
2890            }
2891            catch ( XPathException e )
2892            {
2893                throw new SQLException(
2894                    "evaluating XQuery regular expression: " + e.getMessage(),
2895                    e);
2896            }
2897        }
2898
2899        @Override
2900        public void close()
2901        {
2902            m_ri.close();
2903        }
2904
2905        @Override // MatchVector
2906        public int groups()
2907        {
2908            return m_begPositions.length - 1;
2909        }
2910
2911        @Override
2912        public int position(int groupNumber)
2913        {
2914            return m_begPositions [ groupNumber ];
2915        }
2916
2917        @Override
2918        public int length(int groupNumber)
2919        {
2920            return
2921                m_endPositions [ groupNumber ] - m_begPositions [ groupNumber ];
2922        }
2923
2924        @Override // MatchHandler
2925        public void characters(CharSequence s)
2926        {
2927            m_pos += getStringLength(s);
2928        }
2929
2930        @Override
2931        public void onGroupStart(int groupNumber)
2932        {
2933            m_begPositions [ groupNumber ] = m_pos;
2934        }
2935
2936        @Override
2937        public void onGroupEnd(int groupNumber)
2938        {
2939            m_endPositions [ groupNumber ] = m_pos;
2940        }
2941    }
2942
2943    /**
2944     * Function form of the ISO SQL {@code <regex like predicate>}.
2945     *<p>
2946     * Rewrite the standard form
2947     *<pre>
2948     * value LIKE_REGEX pattern FLAG flags
2949     *</pre>
2950     * into this form:
2951     *<pre>
2952     * like_regex(value, pattern, flag =&gt; flags)
2953     *</pre>
2954     * where the {@code flag} parameter defaults to no flags if omitted.
2955     *<p>
2956     * The SQL standard specifies that pattern elements sensitive to newlines
2957     * (namely {@code ^}, {@code $}, {@code \s}, {@code \S}, and {@code .}) are
2958     * to support the various representations of newline set out in
2959     * <a href='http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr18/#RL1.6'>Unicode Technical
2960     * Standard #18, RL1.6</a>. That behavior differs from the standard W3C
2961     * XQuery newline handling, as described for
2962     * <a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions-31/#flags'>the flags
2963     * {@code m} and {@code s}</a> and for
2964     * <a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema11-2/#cces-mce'>the
2965     * multicharacter escapes {@code \s} and {@code \S}</a>. As an extension to
2966     * ISO SQL, passing {@code w3cNewlines => true} requests the standard W3C
2967     * XQuery behavior rather than the UTS#18 behevior for newlines. If the
2968     * underlying XQuery library only provides the W3C behavior, calls without
2969     * {@code w3cNewlines => true} will throw exceptions.
2970     * @param value The string to be tested against the pattern.
2971     * @param pattern The XQuery regular expression.
2972     * @param flag Optional string of
2973     * <a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions-31/#flags'>flags adjusting
2974     * the regular expression behavior</a>.
2975     * @param w3cNewlines Pass true to allow the regular expression to recognize
2976     * newlines according to the W3C XQuery rules rather than those of ISO SQL.
2977     * @return True if the supplied value matches the pattern. Null if any
2978     * parameter is null.
2979     * @throws SQLException SQLDataException with SQLSTATE 2201S if the regular
2980     * expression is invalid, 2201T if the flags string is invalid;
2981     * SQLFeatureNotSupportedException (0A000) if (in the current
2982     * implementation) w3cNewlines is false or omitted.
2983     */
2984    @Function(schema="javatest")
2985    public static boolean like_regex(
2986        String value,                          //strict
2987        String pattern,                        //strict
2988        @SQLType(defaultValue="") String flag, //strict
2989        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean w3cNewlines
2990    )
2991        throws SQLException
2992    {
2993        newlinesCheck(w3cNewlines, "like_regex");
2994        return compileRE(pattern, flag).containsMatch(value);
2995    }
2996
2997    /**
2998     * Syntax-sugar-free form of the ISO SQL {@code OCCURRENCES_REGEX} function:
2999     * how many times does a pattern occur in a string?
3000     *<p>
3001     * Rewrite the standard form
3002     *<pre>
3003     * OCCURRENCES_REGEX(pattern FLAG flags IN str FROM position USING units)
3004     *</pre>
3005     * into this form:
3006     *<pre>
3007     * occurrences_regex(pattern, flag =&gt; flags, "in" =&gt; str,
3008     *                   "from" =&gt; position, usingOctets =&gt; true|false)
3009     *</pre>
3010     * where all of the named parameters are optional except pattern and "in",
3011     * and the standard {@code USING CHARACTERS} becomes
3012     * {@code usingOctets => false}, which is the default, and
3013     * {@code USING OCTETS} becomes {@code usingOctets => true}. See also
3014     * {@link #like_regex like_regex} regarding the {@code w3cNewlines}
3015     * parameter.
3016     * @param pattern XQuery regular expression to seek in the input string.
3017     * @param in The input string.
3018     * @param flag Optional string of
3019     * <a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions-31/#flags'>flags adjusting
3020     * the regular expression behavior</a>.
3021     * @param from Starting position in the input string, 1 by default.
3022     * @param usingOctets Whether position is counted in characters (actual
3023     * Unicode characters, not any smaller encoded unit, not even Java char),
3024     * which is the default, or (when true) in octets of the string's encoded
3025     * form.
3026     * @param w3cNewlines Pass true to allow the regular expression to recognize
3027     * newlines according to the W3C XQuery rules rather than those of ISO SQL.
3028     * @return The number of occurrences of the pattern in the input string,
3029     * starting from the specified position. Null if any parameter is null; -1
3030     * if the start position is less than 1 or beyond the end of the string.
3031     * @throws SQLException SQLDataException with SQLSTATE 2201S if the regular
3032     * expression is invalid, 2201T if the flags string is invalid;
3033     * SQLFeatureNotSupportedException (0A000) if (in the current
3034     * implementation) usingOctets is true, or w3cNewlines is false or omitted.
3035     */
3036    @Function(schema="javatest")
3037    public static int occurrences_regex(
3038        String pattern,                        //strict
3039        @SQLType(name="\"in\"") String in,     //strict
3040        @SQLType(defaultValue="") String flag, //strict
3041        @SQLType(name="\"from\"", defaultValue="1") int from,
3042        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean usingOctets,
3043        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean w3cNewlines
3044    )
3045        throws SQLException
3046    {
3047        if ( usingAndLengthCheck(in, from, usingOctets, "occurrences_regex") )
3048            return -1; // note: not the same as in position_regex!
3049        newlinesCheck(w3cNewlines, "occurrences_regex");
3050
3051        ListOfMatchVectors lomv = LOMV.of(pattern, flag, in, from);
3052
3053        for ( int i = 1 ;; ++ i )
3054            if ( null == lomv.get(i) )
3055                return i - 1;
3056    }
3057
3058    /**
3059     * Syntax-sugar-free form of the ISO SQL {@code POSITION_REGEX} function:
3060     * where does a pattern, or part of it, occur in a string?
3061     *<p>
3062     * Rewrite the standard forms
3063     *<pre>
3064     * POSITION_REGEX(START pattern FLAG flags IN str FROM position
3065     *                OCCURRENCE n GROUP m)
3066     * POSITION_REGEX(AFTER pattern FLAG flags IN str FROM position
3067     *                OCCURRENCE n GROUP m)
3068     *</pre>
3069     * into these forms, respectively:
3070     *<pre>
3071     * position_regex(pattern, flag =&gt; flags, "in" =&gt; str,
3072     *                "from" =&gt; position, occurrence =&gt; n,
3073     *                "group" =&gt; m)
3074     * position_regex(pattern, flag =&gt; flags, "in" =&gt; str,
3075     *                "from" =&gt; position, occurrence =&gt; n,
3076     *                "group" =&gt; m, after =&gt; true)
3077     *</pre>
3078     * where all of the named parameters are optional except pattern and "in".
3079     * See also {@link #occurrences_regex occurrences_regex} regarding the
3080     * {@code usingOctets} parameter, and {@link #like_regex like_regex}
3081     * regarding {@code w3cNewlines}.
3082     * @param pattern XQuery regular expression to seek in the input string.
3083     * @param in The input string.
3084     * @param flag Optional string of
3085     * <a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions-31/#flags'>flags adjusting
3086     * the regular expression behavior</a>.
3087     * @param from Starting position in the input string, 1 by default.
3088     * @param usingOctets Whether position is counted in characters (actual
3089     * Unicode characters, not any smaller encoded unit, not even Java char),
3090     * which is the default, or (when true) in octets of the string's encoded
3091     * form.
3092     * @param after Whether to return the position where the match starts
3093     * (when false, the default), or just after the match ends (when true).
3094     * @param occurrence If specified as an integer n (default 1), returns the
3095     * position starting (or after) the nth match of the pattern in the string.
3096     * @param group If zero (the default), returns the position starting (or
3097     * after) the match of the whole pattern overall, otherwise if an integer m,
3098     * the position starting or after the mth parenthesized group in (the nth
3099     * occurrence of) the pattern.
3100     * @param w3cNewlines Pass true to allow the regular expression to recognize
3101     * newlines according to the W3C XQuery rules rather than those of ISO SQL.
3102     * @return The position, in the specified units, starting or just after,
3103     * the nth occurrence (or mth capturing group of the nth occurrence) of the
3104     * pattern in the input string, starting from the specified position. Null
3105     * if any parameter is null; zero if the start position is less than 1 or
3106     * beyond the end of the string, if occurrence is less than 1 or greater
3107     * than the number of matches, or if group is less than zero or greater than
3108     * the number of parenthesized capturing groups in the pattern.
3109     * @throws SQLException SQLDataException with SQLSTATE 2201S if the regular
3110     * expression is invalid, 2201T if the flags string is invalid;
3111     * SQLFeatureNotSupportedException (0A000) if (in the current
3112     * implementation) usingOctets is true, or w3cNewlines is false or omitted.
3113     */
3114    @Function(schema="javatest")
3115    public static int position_regex(
3116        String pattern,                                         //strict
3117        @SQLType(name="\"in\"") String in,                      //strict
3118        @SQLType(defaultValue="") String flag,                  //strict
3119        @SQLType(name="\"from\"", defaultValue="1") int from,
3120        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean usingOctets,
3121        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean after,
3122        @SQLType(defaultValue="1") int occurrence,              //strict
3123        @SQLType(name="\"group\"", defaultValue="0") int group, //strict
3124        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean w3cNewlines
3125    )
3126        throws SQLException
3127    {
3128        if ( 1 > occurrence )
3129            return 0;
3130        if ( 0 > group ) // test group > ngroups after compiling regex
3131            return 0;
3132        if ( usingAndLengthCheck(in, from, usingOctets, "position_regex") )
3133            return 0; // note: not the same as in occurrences_regex!
3134        newlinesCheck(w3cNewlines, "position_regex");
3135
3136        ListOfMatchVectors lomv = LOMV.of(pattern, flag, in, from);
3137
3138        MatchVector mv = lomv.get(occurrence);
3139        if ( null == mv  ||  mv.groups() < group )
3140            return 0;
3141
3142        return mv.position(group) + (after ? mv.length(group) : 0);
3143    }
3144
3145    /**
3146     * Syntax-sugar-free form of the ISO SQL {@code SUBSTRING_REGEX} function:
3147     * return a substring specified by a pattern match in a string.
3148     *<p>
3149     * Rewrite the standard form
3150     *<pre>
3151     * SUBSTRING_REGEX(pattern FLAG flags IN str FROM position
3152     *                 OCCURRENCE n GROUP m)
3153     *</pre>
3154     * into this form:
3155     *<pre>
3156     * substring_regex(pattern, flag =&gt; flags, "in" =&gt; str,
3157     *                 "from" =&gt; position, occurrence =&gt; n,
3158     *                 "group" =&gt; m)
3159     *</pre>
3160     * where all of the named parameters are optional except pattern and "in".
3161     * See also {@link #position_regex position_regex} regarding the
3162     * {@code occurrence} and {@code "group"} parameters,
3163     * {@link #occurrences_regex occurrences_regex} regarding
3164     * {@code usingOctets}, and {@link #like_regex like_regex}
3165     * regarding {@code w3cNewlines}.
3166     * @param pattern XQuery regular expression to seek in the input string.
3167     * @param in The input string.
3168     * @param flag Optional string of
3169     * <a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions-31/#flags'>flags adjusting
3170     * the regular expression behavior</a>.
3171     * @param from Starting position in the input string, 1 by default.
3172     * @param usingOctets Whether position is counted in characters (actual
3173     * Unicode characters, not any smaller encoded unit, not even Java char),
3174     * which is the default, or (when true) in octets of the string's encoded
3175     * form.
3176     * @param occurrence If specified as an integer n (default 1), returns the
3177     * nth match of the pattern in the string.
3178     * @param group If zero (the default), returns the match of the whole
3179     * pattern overall, otherwise if an integer m, the match of the mth
3180     * parenthesized group in (the nth occurrence of) the pattern.
3181     * @param w3cNewlines Pass true to allow the regular expression to recognize
3182     * newlines according to the W3C XQuery rules rather than those of ISO SQL.
3183     * @return The substring matching the nth occurrence (or mth capturing group
3184     * of the nth occurrence) of the pattern in the input string, starting from
3185     * the specified position. Null if any parameter is null, if the start
3186     * position is less than 1 or beyond the end of the string, if occurrence is
3187     * less than 1 or greater than the number of matches, or if group is less
3188     * than zero or greater than the number of parenthesized capturing groups in
3189     * the pattern.
3190     * @throws SQLException SQLDataException with SQLSTATE 2201S if the regular
3191     * expression is invalid, 2201T if the flags string is invalid;
3192     * SQLFeatureNotSupportedException (0A000) if (in the current
3193     * implementation) usingOctets is true, or w3cNewlines is false or omitted.
3194     */
3195    @Function(schema="javatest")
3196    public static String substring_regex(
3197        String pattern,                                          //strict
3198        @SQLType(name="\"in\"") String in,                       //strict
3199        @SQLType(defaultValue="") String flag,                   //strict
3200        @SQLType(name="\"from\"", defaultValue="1") int from,
3201        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean usingOctets,
3202        @SQLType(defaultValue="1") int occurrence,               //strict
3203        @SQLType(name="\"group\"", defaultValue="0") int group,  //strict
3204        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean w3cNewlines
3205    )
3206        throws SQLException
3207    {
3208        if ( 1 > occurrence )
3209            return null;
3210        if ( 0 > group ) // test group > ngroups after compiling regex
3211            return null;
3212        if ( usingAndLengthCheck(in, from, usingOctets, "substring_regex") )
3213            return null;
3214        newlinesCheck(w3cNewlines, "substring_regex");
3215
3216        ListOfMatchVectors lomv = LOMV.of(pattern, flag, in, from);
3217
3218        MatchVector mv = lomv.get(occurrence);
3219        if ( null == mv  ||  mv.groups() < group )
3220            return null;
3221
3222        int codePointPos = mv.position(group);
3223        int codePointLen = mv.length(group);
3224
3225        int utf16pos = in.offsetByCodePoints(0, codePointPos - 1);
3226        int utf16end = in.offsetByCodePoints(utf16pos, codePointLen);
3227
3228        return in.substring(utf16pos, utf16end);
3229    }
3230
3231    /**
3232     * Syntax-sugar-free form of the ISO SQL {@code TRANSLATE_REGEX} function:
3233     * return a string constructed from the input string by replacing one
3234     * specified occurrence, or all occurrences, of a matching pattern.
3235     *<p>
3236     * Rewrite the standard forms
3237     *<pre>
3238     * TRANSLATE_REGEX(pattern FLAG flags IN str WITH repl FROM position
3239     *                 OCCURRENCE ALL)
3240     * TRANSLATE_REGEX(pattern FLAG flags IN str WITH repl FROM position
3241     *                 OCCURRENCE n)
3242     *</pre>
3243     * into these forms, respectively:
3244     *<pre>
3245     * translate_regex(pattern, flag =&gt; flags, "in" =&gt; str,
3246     *                 "with" =&gt; repl, "from" =&gt; position)
3247     * translate_regex(pattern, flag =&gt; flags, "in" =&gt; str,
3248     *                 "with" =&gt; repl, "from" =&gt; position,
3249     *                 occurrence =&gt; n)
3250     *</pre>
3251     * where all of the named parameters are optional except pattern and "in"
3252     * (the default for "with" is the empty string, resulting in matches being
3253     * deleted).
3254     * See also {@link #position_regex position_regex} regarding the
3255     * {@code occurrence} parameter,
3256     * {@link #occurrences_regex occurrences_regex} regarding
3257     * {@code usingOctets}, and {@link #like_regex like_regex}
3258     * regarding {@code w3cNewlines}.
3259     *<p>
3260     * For the specified occurrence (or all occurrences), the matching portion
3261     * <em>s</em> of the string is replaced as by the XQuery function
3262     * <a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions-31/#func-replace'
3263     * >replace</a>(<em>s, pattern, repl, flags</em>). The <em>repl</em> string
3264     * may contain {@code $0} to refer to the entire matched substring, or
3265     * {@code $}<em>m</em> to refer to the <em>m</em>th parenthesized capturing
3266     * group in the pattern.
3267     * @param pattern XQuery regular expression to seek in the input string.
3268     * @param in The input string.
3269     * @param flag Optional string of
3270     * <a href='https://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions-31/#flags'>flags adjusting
3271     * the regular expression behavior</a>.
3272     * @param with The replacement string, possibly with $m references.
3273     * @param from Starting position in the input string, 1 by default.
3274     * @param usingOctets Whether position is counted in characters (actual
3275     * Unicode characters, not any smaller encoded unit, not even Java char),
3276     * which is the default, or (when true) in octets of the string's encoded
3277     * form.
3278     * @param occurrence If specified as an integer n (default 0 for "ALL"),
3279     * replace the nth match of the pattern in the string.
3280     * @param w3cNewlines Pass true to allow the regular expression to recognize
3281     * newlines according to the W3C XQuery rules rather than those of ISO SQL.
3282     * @return The input string with one occurrence or all occurences of the
3283     * pattern replaced, as described above. Null if any parameter is null, or
3284     * if the start position is less than 1 or beyond the end of the string.
3285     * The input string unchanged if occurrence is less than zero or exceeds the
3286     * number of matches.
3287     * @throws SQLException SQLDataException with SQLSTATE 2201S if the regular
3288     * expression is invalid, 2201T if the flags string is invalid; 2201U if
3289     * replacing where the pattern has matched a substring of zero length; 2201V
3290     * if the replacement string has improper form (a backslash must be used to
3291     * escape any dollar sign or backslash intended literally);
3292     * SQLFeatureNotSupportedException (0A000) if (in the current
3293     * implementation) usingOctets is true, or w3cNewlines is false or omitted.
3294     */
3295    @Function(schema="javatest")
3296    public static String translate_regex(
3297        String pattern,                                          //strict
3298        @SQLType(name="\"in\"") String in,                       //strict
3299        @SQLType(defaultValue="") String flag,                   //strict
3300        @SQLType(name="\"with\"", defaultValue="") String with,  //strict
3301        @SQLType(name="\"from\"", defaultValue="1") int from,
3302        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean usingOctets,
3303        @SQLType(defaultValue="0" /* ALL */) int occurrence,
3304        @SQLType(defaultValue="false") boolean w3cNewlines
3305    )
3306        throws SQLException
3307    {
3308        if ( usingAndLengthCheck(in, from, usingOctets, "translate_regex") )
3309            return null;
3310        newlinesCheck(w3cNewlines, "translate_regex");
3311        if ( 0 > occurrence )
3312            return in;
3313
3314        RegularExpression re = compileRE(pattern, flag);
3315
3316        ListOfMatchVectors lomv = LOMV.of(re, in, from);
3317
3318        MatchVector mv;
3319        int codePointPos;
3320        int codePointLen;
3321        int utf16pos;
3322        int utf16end;
3323
3324        if ( 0 < occurrence )
3325        {
3326            mv = lomv.get(occurrence);
3327            if ( null == mv )
3328                return in;
3329
3330            codePointPos = mv.position(0);
3331            codePointLen = mv.length(0);
3332
3333            utf16pos = in.offsetByCodePoints(0, codePointPos - 1);
3334            utf16end = in.offsetByCodePoints(utf16pos, codePointLen);
3335
3336            return
3337                in.substring(0, utf16pos)
3338                + replace(re, in.substring(utf16pos, utf16end), with)
3339                + in.substring(utf16end);
3340        }
3341
3342        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
3343        utf16end = 0;
3344
3345        for ( int i = 1; null != (mv = lomv.get(i)); ++ i )
3346        {
3347            codePointPos = mv.position(0);
3348            codePointLen = mv.length(0);
3349
3350            utf16pos = in.offsetByCodePoints(0, codePointPos - 1);
3351
3352            sb.append(in.substring(utf16end, utf16pos));
3353
3354            utf16end = in.offsetByCodePoints(utf16pos, codePointLen);
3355
3356            sb.append(replace(re, in.substring(utf16pos, utf16end), with));
3357        }
3358
3359        return sb.append(in.substring(utf16end)).toString();
3360    }
3361}
